DOC.HEAD: Storm Slams Taiwan, Killing Seven; Heads for China
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE death toll to seven in Taiwan, 35 missing; Ofelia downgraded to tropical storm, heading for China. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Ofelia was downgraded to a tropical storm on Sunday, a day after it slammed into eastern Taiwan with 85 mph winds, killing seven people and leaving 35 others missing. The storm also left 30 people dead in the Philippines. On Sunday, Ofelia was bearing down on the Chinese province of Zhejiang, but its winds had weakened to 50 mph, forecasters said. Taiwan police said seven people drowned or died in landslides and 35 others were missing in and around the eastern coastal city of Hualien, 124 miles southeast of Taipei. Most of the missing were swept away by floods that inundated more than 200 homes in villages, police said. Some villages were under three feet of water, and authorities estimated property and crop damage at more than $3.6 million. Two Panamanian ships were pounded by Ofelia off Hualien on Saturday. The 10,890-ton freighter Cahaya broke up into three sections in heavy seas, police reported. Its 24-member Indonesian crew was rescued, they said. Another 28 crewmen from the Panamanian freighter Juliana were rescued when their 7,000-ton vessel broke loose from its moorning and ran aground, the officials said. Taiwan police said air and road links in the county were disrupted by landslides and flooding from the storm. They reported that 18 inches of rain was recorded in one area in a 24-hour span. Authorities canceled all domestic flights. Ofelia also buffeted the island's north and south with strong winds, but no damage or casualties were reported. The storm forced 84,600 people to flee their homes in the Philippines as it swept through Luzon island with rain and strong winds, according to the Red Cross and other relief agencies. The hardest-hit community in the Philippines was La Union, 150 miles northwest of Manila, where at least 22 people drowned or were crushed to death in landslides, relief officials said. In Pangasinan, west of La Union, two people were electrocuted. In the Manila suburb of Pasig, three children died when a concrete wall collapsed on their shanty, officials said. A 4-year-old girl died in a landslide in the mountain resort city of Baguio. Two other people were killed by lightning during a thunderstorm unleashed by Ofelia in Lanao del Sur province on Mindanao island, about 520 miles south of Manila.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Airliner Hijacked to Finland; Hijacker Surrenders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with asylum request, hijacker's age, bomb threat, CORRECTS destination of plane, adds byline. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Last Tuesday...'
DOC.TEXT: A young hijacker surrendered to police Sunday after forcing a Soviet airliner on a domestic flight to land in Finland, authorities said. The 72 passengers and six crew members were released unharmed. Police Commissioner Pentti Luntiala, speaking to reporters, quoted the 21-year-old man as saying he wanted to seek political asylum and go to the United States. It was the second Soviet hijack incident in Finland in a week and the third in a Scandinavian country in two weeks. There was also a fourth incident involving the commandeering of a Soviet aircraft with no passengers aboard. The hijacker commandeered the twin-engine Tupolev 134, bound from the Estonian capital of Tallinn to Lvov in the Ukraine, by saying he carried a bomb in his luggage, an official at Helsinki's international airport said. The official, terminal duty officer Pirjo Lahteela, said police were searching the plane for explosives and the hijacker was being interrogated. The Aeroflot airliner landed at Helsinki's international airport at about 8:30 a.m. (1:30 a.m. EDT) time, authorities said. Last Tuesday, a 20-year-old hijacker forced a Soviet airliner with 60 people aboard to land in Finland and asked for political asylum. No one was injured in that incident. Moscow asked Helsinki to extradite the hijacker, identified as Oleg Kozlov. A day earlier, a 29-year-old pilot, Valeri Yuricevic, commandeered a 12-seat Antonov-2 aircraft in Izmail, near the Ukrainian port of Odessa, and flew to Turkey, where he asked for asylum. There was no one else on board. On June 9, Dimitry Semionov, a 17-year-old Soviet youth, used a fake hand grenade to hijack a plane carrying 121 passengers during a flight from Minsk to Murmansk. That plane was forced to fly to Stockholm, where Semionov surrendered. The youth said later through a lawyer he had acted on impulse after a family quarrel and wanted to go to a ``free country.'' Semionov was arraigned in a Stockholm court and could face up to four years in prison, depending on the results of psychiatric tests.

DOC.HEAD: High Wind, Heavy Rain Leave Boy Dead, Palau Battered
DOC.TEXT: High wind and heavy rain from Typhoon Percy battered Palau on Sunday night, leaving a child dead and knocking out utility service, a newspaper reported. A young boy died Saturday night when he was swept by rain into mangrove trees near his home in the cluster of islands that comprise Palau, the Pacific Daily News said. The storm passed 90 miles north of Palau, which is 800 miles south of Agana, said Navy Ensign Richard Jeffries of the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The typhoon moved west-northwest at 16 mph on a path that could take it between Taiwan and the Philippines in four or five days, Jeffries said. Wind gusts of up to 103 mph blew off tin roofs of many buildings and knocked radio and television stations off the air, the Pacific Daily News said. Airline flights into the republic were canceled, the newspaper said. Earlier Sunday, the typhoon's winds battered Yap Island in the neighboring Federated States of Micronesia, collapsing about 30 houses and damaging banana and coconut plantations, police said. There were no reports of injuries on Yap, and the winds and accompanying heavy rains posed no problems for the island's electric and water systems, Officer Kenneth Chugrad said.

DOC.HEAD: UN: Iranian Authorities Fear Death Toll May Reach 50,000
DOC.TEXT: Iranian authorities fear that the death toll in Thursday's devastating earthquake may reach 50,000, a senior U.N. relief official said Sunday. Previous figures on the number of deaths had varied, but officials had said earlier an estimated 40,000 were feared dead. M'Hamed Essaafi also said parts of the stricken area were still inaccessible because roads in the Caspian Sea region were blocked by landslides and rain. Essaafi spoke at a press briefing after meeting with the head of the Iranian mission to the U.N. office in Geneva, Ambassador Sirous Nasseri. He said Nasseri again stressed that Iran was more urgently in need of relief supplies than in rescue personnel. He said the number of injured was still believed to be about 100,000, but there was no confirmed figure yet. He said the homeless numbered about half a million. About 6,000 injured people are being treated in Tehran hospitals, according to the Iranian authorities. Hospitals in the affected provinces are filled to capacity, Essaafi added, quoting official Iranian reports. Essaafi, named by U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to oversee the international earthquake relief effort, said he did not think there was any effort by the Iranians to underreport the casualty figure. An Iranian resistance movement, Mujahedeen Khalq, had made such an accusation. Essaafi said that during the next two days at least 32 relief flights from nine countries were scheduled to land at Tehran airport. He said they included 11 planes from West Germany carrying 145 tons of supplies, plus a field hospital with two medial teams, and nine flights from Turkey. Other flights announced to the office of the U.N. Disaster Relief Coordinator, UNDRO, were to arrive from Bangladesh, Japan, Canada, Cuba, Czechoslovakia Pakistan, Switzerland and Britain, he said.. Iran also asked for help from U.N. experts in improving communications, which continued to pose problems in the quake zone. The International Red Cross said Friday Iran expressly stated it did not want satellite communications equipment to be included in the relief supplies. The U.N. official, who will leave for Tehran on Monday, said that the situation was being ``handed rather well by Iran.'' Since the predawn quake on Thursday, more than 200 aftershocks have hit the region, the biggest registering 4.2 on the Richter scale and rocking the Tarom-e Olia region about 125 miles northwest of Tehran, the official Islamic Republic News Agency said. Thursday's quake was at least 7.3 on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEAD: Aftershock Hits Devastated Area
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The aftershock...' with 1 graf to ADD details on aftershock. Pick up 8th pvs, `Rasht is...'
DOC.TEXT: The strongest aftershock in three days hit a quake-devastated northern province Sunday, and a moderate earthquake was reported in southern Iran. The stench of decomposing bodies hung over Gilan and Zanjan provinces, the two hardest hit in Thursday's earthquake, as rescuers aided by police dogs pulled corpses from the rubble and quickly buried them in mass graves to stem the outbreak of disease. A senior U.N. relief official said Sunday in Geneva that authorities fear the death toll may reach 50,000. Some official Iranian reports have set the toll at 40,000. Tehran Times, the nation's leading English-language newspaper, quoted an unnamed official as saying 50,000 people died and 200,000 were injured in the quake. He said even that was a conservative estimate because ``the figures are quoted taking account only of those who have been registered officially as dead or wounded.'' ``There are areas where bodies were buried without counting them,'' he was quoted as saying. Tehran University's Geophysics Center reported 60 aftershocks in the northern provinces, the strongest of which jolted Rasht, capital of Gilan province, at 1:16 p.m. (5:46 a.m. EDT) Sunday. It measured 5.7 on the Richter scale. The aftershock was the worst since several Thursday shortly following the quake. IRNA said details of casualties or damage from the aftershock were not immediately available, but ``the Rasht-Rudbar road, which had just been reopened, was once again blocked by the latest tremor which caused a mountain slide.'' Rasht is 35 miles north of Rudbar, which is on the border between Gilan and Zanjan provinces. The Geophysics Center also reported a moderate earthquake measuring 4.9 on the Richter scale in southern Iran at 8.39 a.m. (1:09 p.m.). It caused no casualties or damage. No further details were available. The center, in a statement carried by the official Islamic Republic News Agency, said 360 tremors have struck northern Iran since the quake. The aftershocks have caused massive landslides, blocking many roads leading to demolished villages on the northern edge of Gilan, on the Caspian Sea. IRNA, monitored in Cyprus, said: ``More than 72 hours after the horrifying earthquake, many villages in the mountainous region which have been leveled remain inaccessible.'' The agency quoted a survivor from Ab-bor village in Zanjan as saying: ``So many bodies have perished under the rubble. They have not been retrieved or buried. ``The whole area is stinking because of the decaying corpses which make rescue operations even more difficult,'' the survivor, identified as Ahmad Ali, was quoted as saying. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph.

DOC.HEAD: 7,000 Penguins Die in Mystery Stampede
DOC.TEXT: King penguins at a rookery on a nearby island stampeded, killing 7,000 of the birds, and officials said Sunday they were investigating the mysterious occurrence. ``We don't know at this stage why they stampeded _ we have not observed this type of behavior before,'' a spokesman for the Australian State Parks Wildlife and Heritage Ministry said on condition of anonymity. The stampede occurred on Macquarie Island, which is midway between Australia and Antarctica and part of Tasmania, an Australian state. The parks spokesman said about 6,000 chicks and 800 to 1,000 adults were found dead about three weeks ago on the island. ``There was no one in the area at the time, and we have ruled out earthquakes,'' he said. ``There is a lot of seismic activity on Macquarie Island, but there was no activity on that day.'' Macquarie Island's Lusitiana Bay is home to hundreds of thousands of birds and the site of one of the world's biggest king penguin rookeries.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Restores Diplomatic Ties With Libya, Names Ambassador
DOC.TEXT: Jordan on Sunday announced the appointment of an ambassador to Libya, formally ending a six-year diplomatic rift with the northern African Arab country. The official Jordanian news agency Petra said Prime Minister Mudar Badran named Hisham Muheisen as ambassador. Muheisen had led a senior Jordanian delegation to Tripoli in April to reopen the Jordanian Embassy there for the first time since the Arab nations severed diplomatic relations in 1984. Jordan closed its embassy that year after Libyan students attacked the building during demonstrations protesting reported efforts by Jordan to negotiate peace with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Edward Sees His Greyhound Run Second
DOC.TEXT: A touted greyhound part-owned by Prince Edward finished second in the Greyhound Derby, dog racing's richest prize. Queen Elizabeth's youngest son was at Wimbledon Stadium Saturday night to see his dog, Druids Johno, the 4-7 favorite, beaten by 8-1 shot Slippy Blue. Slippy Blue lost two heats to Druids Johno but ran the final 525-yard circuit in 28.7 seconds for the $69,200 first prize. Edward, 26, said he would donate his share of the $13,800 second-place winnings to a fund for injured victims of an Irish Republican Army bombing of the military music school. Ten people died in the 1989 attack. Edward dropped out of military training to take a backstage job in the London theater. He owns the dog with Irish trainer Patsy Byrne.

DOC.HEAD: German Economic Merger a Double-Edged Sword For Europe
DOC.TEXT: The economic merger of the Germanys on July 1 probably will be a double-edged sword for the rest of Europe. Experts feel it will spur general economic growth and speed the march toward a single European market, but also may give West Germany, already the strongest economy by far, even more influence over the continent's economic affairs. The Germans believe they have a strategy that will merge the two economies with minimum shock to the rest of Europe, but there are unknowns. If the union increases inflation, German interest rates may rise and the other Western European economies, linked in an exchange-rate system, may have to follow. The economic merger is the first major step toward reunification of East and West Germany. On July 1, the West German mark becomes the currency of East Germany and the Germanys will merge their economic machinery to create what their treaty calls ``identical social market systems.'' That means East Germany's communist economic regulations will be replaced by West Germany's corporate, union and welfare practices. ``Overall, it should provide a bit of a spur of growth around Europe over the longer term,'' said Stephen King, international economist with the London investment firm James Capel and Co. ``It should be good for the other European export sectors.'' Britain's National Institute of Economic and Social Research said in a report: ``The rest of Europe is expected to benefit both from higher demand in Germany and also marginally because of increased centrally planned economies' imports.'' Neighboring Holland, which sells one-fourth of its exports to Germany, expects to benefit even if unification proves bumpy. ``In the long run, it will be a boon for the Dutch,'' said Chen Ie Lie, an analyst for Banque Paribas Amsterdam. ``People can't do without things like cheese, poultry and pork.'' More truck drivers could be employed in hauling foreign goods from the Dutch port of Rotterdam, Europe's busiest, to Germany. There also are worries. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said in mid-June that a unified Germany within a federal Europe ``would be dominant both in numbers and political and economic power.'' Asked whether that worried her, Mrs. Thatcher said, ``Yes ... and I think many people in Europe are a little bit apprehensive about a unified Germany.'' King said: ``Quite clearly, the other Europeans are worried about having such a large Germany in the center of Europe. ``There is of course the fear that Germany's economy makes it much more politically powerful as a whole and raises its prestige and raises its power in the European Community.'' A united Germany will have a population of nearly 80 million. West Germany's gross national product last year was $1.2 trillion, more than 25 percent greater than second-place France. The central Bundesbank, with its traditionally tight, inflation-fighting monetary policy, already dominates European monetary affairs. Unification of Germany within the context of Western European integration greatly complicates the economic and political issues. In 1992, the 12 European Community nations are to scrap trade barriers and become a single market. Germany and France want a single European currency and a single central bank. Britain is opposed, but the National Institute report said monetary integration appeared to have gained support in recent months. Peter Pietsch, an economist with Commerzbank in Frankfurt, said: ``Of course Germany has a big economic importance and the importance will grow. I don't see how this would be a bad influence.'' ``We want to be a group of countries with the same target and the same goal'' of low inflation, he said in an interview. ``We are European, we feel European. I think that is much more important than the isolated importance of one country.'' King said France and the Netherlands hope an integrated Europe will spread power more evenly, but Germany ``would like to impose more strongly a Bundesbank on the whole of Europe and essentially make a deutsche mark bloc.'' Hans Jaeckel, senior German economist for the private forecasting firm DRI Europe in Frankfurt, said European integration should be hastened to create a ``less German-dominated'' Europe. John Major, Britain's chancellor of the exchequer, takes the opposite view. ``There are those who see in the hectic pace of change in the East a reason for urging similarly hectic change within the Community,'' he told the German Chamber of Industry and Commerce in London. ``Speed is of no advantage if you go in the wrong direction. Better to build slowly and well.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Nervous About Book by Governor's Ex-Wife
DOC.TEXT: Republicans can't wait to get their hands on an upcoming book by the ex-wife of Democratic Gov. James Blanchard. Nervous Democrats wish they could put it on hold until after the November elections. Paula Blanchard says both sides are overreacting. Her book covering the 1987 breakup of her 21-year marriage to Blanchard is due out in July. Blanchard, who last year married Janet Fox, his former secretary, is favored for re-election this fall over likely GOP opponent John Engler, the state Senate majority leader. Paula Blanchard's book _ ``'Til Politics Do Us Part'' _ is a question mark in the campaign, but Michigan's former first lady predicts it won't affect the election. ``This book is not a kiss-and-tell book,'' she said. ``This book is not an exercise in vengefulness or anything like that. It's the story of my life as a political spouse and the choices I made and why I made the choices.'' Paula Blanchard supports her ex-husbands's re-election bid and predicts he will win ``based on his solid record of performance.'' Engler offers a different assessment. He describes Michigan as overtaxed, sputtering economically, and in need of a new leader. He contends Blanchard masks an average record with a high-powered public relations machine. ``Just think what the right man could do,'' is the theme of his campaign. Engler himself is divorced, and his ex-wife, Colleen, also has written a book that touches on the breakup of their marriage. Colleen Engler, a former state legislator and onetime gubernatorial candidate who works for the Commerce Department in Washington, said she doesn't have a publisher yet. ``It hasn't even been edited yet. An editor might say, `You don't want any of this stuff about John Engler in there,''' she said. ``My book is about running for governor in 1986 and then running for lieutenant governor.'' Blanchard's divorce made front-page news, as did his remarriage, but there has been no backlash from voters. In fact, the newlyweds got a warm welcome earlier this month on a two-day tour to announce his bid for a third four-year term. Paula Blanchard said the governor and a number of his associates asked her to hold up her book until after the election. ``The curious thing is none of them have read it,'' she said. ``They were asking me to hold it based on speculation and assumptions.'' ``I've encouraged Jim to read the book. After he does that, his concerns about it will be minimized. He will be able to see it's a book that puts a lot into perspective,'' she said. ``It goes directly from my heart to the page.'' Blanchard is unopposed in Michigan's Aug. 7 primary, while Engler is expected to easily defeat tax fighter John Lauve. A March poll found Blanchard leading Engler 51 percent to 31 percent, but the lesser-known Engler said that was to be expected early in the campaign. Engler launched his campaign in February and immediately began airing television ads aimed at boosting his name identification. Democrats say Engler's leadership is untested and focus on Blanchard's record in erasing a $1.7 billion debt, his efforts to diversify the state's economy, improve education, and fight crime while keeping the state budget balanced. The governor's first TV ad, unveiled last month, touted Blanchard as tough on crime and set out his campaign theme, ``Tough. Tested. Trusted.'' The ad closed with a white guard yelling at a black inmate at Michigan's boot camp prison for non-violent young offenders, who volunteer for its military-style discipline. The ad was aired everywhere in the state except Detroit, which is two-thirds black. Engler's campaign director, Dan Pero, denounced it as racist, and some black leaders and lawmakers agreed. The ad later aired in Detroit. Blanchard defended it as showing a real answer to a tough problem and dismissed the whole controversy as being manufactured by Republicans. The flap ended quickly and Michigan Democratic Party Chairman Tom Lewand said it was ``well behind us and not something to be concerned about.'' But Engler sees cracks in Blanchard's public image, and cites the boot camp ad, tight budgets ahead and 78-year-old Lt. Gov. Martha Griffiths' decision not to retire _ which came as a surprise to the governor. ``The carefully constructed facade is in tatters,'' Engler said. ``This is a very isolated administration that isn't as finely tuned and well-oiled as people would believe.''

DOC.HEAD: Radical Paper Blames U.S., In Part, For Quake Damage
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An anti-American newspaper in Iran said Sunday the United States is partly to blame for the death of tens of thousands of people in last week's earthquake. The ``criminal role of America in Iran's past became evident once again in the recent earthquake,'' the Jomhuri Islami said in an editorial reported by the official Islamic Republic News Agency. ``Our people, even under the rubble, chant `Death to America' and pray to God to cut off the hands of the United States ... even those hands stretched out to help,'' it said. It argued that by ``plundering Iran's oil and other resources'' for 25 years, the United States had prevented the use of even a small part of the national wealth for urban development projects and ``advanced (anti-seismic) building construction systems.'' ``Even after its expulsion from Iran, the U.S. government by imposing economic sanctions and launching several other plots, halted the renovation of the country,'' the editorial added. The newspaper was implying that with these actions the United States had blocked the diversion of funds to earthquake safety measures. ``If the United States has real humanitarian objectives and intended to help the Iranian nation, it should do only one thing, stop hatching plots,'' the newspaper said. It called on Iranians to reject relief offers by the United States and ``other governments whose hands are stained with the blood of the Iranian people.'' Iran, at odds with the United States since the 1979 seizure of hostages at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, has said it would welcome relief from the American Red Cross and other U.S. humanitarian groups. The two nations have no diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEAD: Nationwide Raids To Hit Public-Housing Drug Dealers This Week
DOC.TEXT: Public housing tenants known to deal drugs will be kicked out of their apartments during nationwide raids set to begin this week even if they haven't been convicted of a crime, officials say. Federal marshals are scheduled Monday to begin raiding apartments in housing projects located in as many as 22 cities where the holder of the lease is a known drug dealer and could be prosecuted for two felonies, officials said. The tenant and his or her family may be kicked out of the apartment even if the person has not yet been convicted of a drug crime under the program first announced last month by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, officials said. The government calls the actions ``leasehold forfeitures'' _ not evictions. The plan already has stirred up a legal challenge in one city. The forfeiture of public-housing leases by known drug dealers is specifically authorized by asset-forfeiture provisions of the 1988 Anti-Drug Abuse Act, government officials say. The same provisions enable federal prosecutors to seize boats, cars and cash of drug dealers awaiting trial. In this case, the lease is the asset to be seized. The raids are scheduled to be conducted in cities where authorities have identified drug dealing in housing projects as a significant problem. The targeted housing projects are in some of the nation's largest cities _ New York, Los Angeles, Chicago _ as well as smaller municipalities such as Chandler, Ariz., Tacoma, Wash., and Frederick, Md., according to a list obtained by The Associated Press. Bob Nipp, a spokesman for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, declined to comment on the planned raids. When Kemp first announced the plan, he declined to identify the cities where housing projects would be raided. Civil libertarians have criticized the planned raids, saying they will violate the principle that a person is innocent of criminal wrongdoing until proven guilty. Legal aid lawyers in Richmond, Va., _ one of the targeted cities _ last week obtained a temporary restraining order from a federal judge barring the government from removing tenants without giving them advance notice and an opportunity to be heard. The order by U.S. District Judge Richard L. Williams, in effect, affords tenants some of the due process of eviction proceedings. It only applies to the Richmond area but legal aid lawyers are expected to seek similar court rulings in other cities. Under guidelines adopted by the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Justice Department, only apartments that are notorious and open sites of drug distribution and leased by known drug dealers will be raided, officials said. The guidelines also state that authorities should have ``proof beyond a reasonable doubt'' that the leaseholder committed at least two felony drug crimes and will face prosecution, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. It was not known if authorities also planned to serve search warrants to seek possible evidence of drug activity. The plan calls for using local social service agencies to relocate children and elderly people who will be displaced from their homes by the raids, officials said. Public housing projects in the following cities also have been targeted: Washington; Atlanta; Dallas; Baltimore; Hartford, Conn.; Newark, N.J.; Indianapolis; Flint, Mich.; Charleston, S.C.; Macon, Ga.; El Paso, Texas; Kansas City; Omaha; Portland, Ore.; and St. Louis, Mo.

DOC.HEAD: You Thought the Blackbird Was Retired? Think Again
DOC.TEXT: When last seen, the SR-71 Blackbird spy plane was slicing through a dreary March sky for a record-setting, final, coast-to-coast flight that touched off regrets and doubts over its retirement. The Air Force and Congress had decided several months earlier that the reconnaissance aircraft which provided unsurpassed snooping during the Cold War had become too costly and that satellites could do the job easily. Shortly after its 68-minute, 17-second trip from Los Angeles to Washington, Blackbird No. 17972 was shipped off to the Smithsonian Institution. But the Blackbird wasn't quite dead yet. Tucked away in the report accompanying a $4 billion spending bill that President Bush signed last month was a provision telling the Pentagon to maintain at least six of the spy planes for use in the event of a national crisis. ``The above outlined program should not be considered a charter for re-establishment of SR-71 flight operations which were terminated as a part of the fiscal 1990 budget deliberations,'' the report said. Rather, the intent of the lawmakers' action was to ensure that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which will receive three of the planes, has enough funds to conduct aeronautics research and that the Air Force could begin flight operations within 90 days of an emergency. The report even designated the aircraft by tail numbers for the contingency program. Although the report provision is non-binding, Pentagon refusal to adhere to the language would be too costly in the tenuous relationship between Congress and the Bush administration. Thus, behind-the-scenes negotiations have been going on between the Air Force and several congressional committees over the report language. And the cost to maintain the black, dagger-shaped planes is a major issue. Lawmakers and congressional sources, who requested anonymity, said Air Force Gen. Michael J. Dugan told members of Congress that the cost of maintenance would total $30 million. Dugan is commander of the Air Force in Europe and President Bush's nominee for chief of staff, a selection the Senate Armed Services Committee approved last week. The report said the Air Force should use $6 million of money it already has for upkeep of the aircraft. Shortly before Pentagon and congressional negotiators sought a common ground on the issue, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney staked out his position in testimony before the Senate Appropriations defense subcommittee. ``We can park them,'' Cheney told the panel earlier this month. ``We can't bring them back within 90 days without going back and spending a lot of money to reconstitute at least a portion of manpower and maintenance and so forth and recertify pilots.'' Dugan, in his Senate confirmation hearing, complained of the ``conflicting guidance from the Congress'' on the issue. ``The resources to get the five or six airplanes ... operational within a 90-day period _ those resources are considerably more than made available,'' Dugan told the Armed Services panel. Rep. Joseph McDade of Pennsylvania, ranking Republican on the House Appropriations subcommittee on defense, said lawmakers did not believe the report provision was ``an unreasonable disposition'' for the spy plane. The Blackbird regularly flew missions over heavily defended North Vietnam and provided intelligence in many other regions, including the Middle East, China and the Persian Gulf. The plane can outrun the fastest fighters and has never been shot down. Built to withstand temperatures of more than 800 degrees Fahrenheit, its skin is a titanium alloy instead of the aluminum used on most airplanes. It can sustain a speed of Mach 3, or three times the speed of sound, but its maximum speed is classified. McDade noted that Cheney, during his tenure as a Wyoming congressman on the House Intelligence Committee, had opposed the Blackbird. ``Cheney always felt the system was not a cost-effective system. He didn't think it justified the expenditures,'' McDade said in an interview last week. Congressional sources said the provision in the spending bill report was perceived by the Armed Services, Intelligence and Appropriations committees as the best opportunity to resolve the issue and negotiations were going well. If they fail, however, the question of the highflying Blackbird is certain to surface in next year's defense bills, which Congress will begin crafting later this summer. ``They're not going to re-create the SR-71, but it's not going away lock, stock and barrel,'' one congressional source said.

DOC.HEAD: Right-Wing Groups Join Forces, Pledge Support For Extremist
DOC.TEXT: Two extreme right-wing groups signed a cooperation agreement Sunday in the latest effort by pro-apartheid whites to build opposition to reforms instituted by President F.W. de Klerk. The groups also pledged support for a white fugitive who has declared war on the government. Both de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela have warned that heavily armed right-wing extremists could undermine efforts to launch black-white negotiations on a new constitution and ending apartheid. The Boer Resistance Movement and the Boer State Party announced Sunday they would work together to establish a homeland for the Boers, or Afrikaners, the country's Dutch-descended settlers who account for 3 million of the 5 million whites. The two groups, which are believed to have several thousand followers among them, are among several right-wing organizations that favor strict segregation and oppose all concessions to South Africa's 28 million blacks. The organizations consider the ANC, the country's largest black opposition group, a communist-led terrorist movement. The right-wing groups ``promised all possible legal support'' for Piet Rudolph, a member of the Boer State Party who declared war on de Klerk's government last week. Rudolph has been in hiding since he allegedly stole arms and ammunition from an air force base in April. He made his declaration of war in a videotape sent to a newspaper. The government has offered a $19,000 reward for information leading to Rudolph's arrest. The two Afrikaner groups said they had established a fund to help ``all the other unknown Piet Rudolphs ... who have to flee from the de Klerk-Mandela Communists.'' Right-wingers have been threatening the government for months. Events of the past week provided the strongest indications yet that such groups are ready to act. Among them: _Two offices belonging to de Klerk's National Party were bombed Friday night, causing extensive damage but no injuries. No one has claimed responsibility, but government officials say right-wing whites are the most likely suspects. _An Afrikaans-language newspaper reported Friday that white extremists were planning to assassinate Mandela and de Klerk and poison drinking water in Soweto, the huge black township outside Johannesburg. Police arrested 11 whites for questioning, but all were released Friday and no charges have been filed. Most political analysts believe that an increasing number of whites are joining right-wing groups in response to de Klerk's reforms. The pro-apartheid Conservative Party captured 31 percent of the vote in white elections last September and would probably improve on that figure if polls were held at present, analysts say. De Klerk says he wants to end racial discrimination in South Africa and negotiate a constitution that allows blacks and whites to share power. Under the current apartheid system, whites control the government and the economy.

DOC.HEAD: 27 Killed As Gov't Troops Advance Toward Town `Waiting to Die'
DOC.TEXT: Government troops hunting for Tamil rebels crept forward Sunday from two sides towards war-ravaged Batticaloa, and residents said the city was ``waiting to die.'' A Defense Ministry statement said 16 soldiers and 11 separatists were killed in fighting that has already left more than 1,400 combatants and an unknown number of civilians dead. Residents of Batticaloa, on the eastern coast, said they feared reprisals by government troops, who are mostly Sinhalese, because the rebels burned police stations and Sinhalese shops before fleeing into the jungles. ``We are like a drum, beaten on both sides. First the Tigers threatened and killed many of us, and now government soldiers are coming. We can only pray,'' said a hotel owner on condition of anonymity. The city has been without electricity and transport since the fighting began. Military officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the troops were approaching Batticaloa from Chenkaladi in the north and Kalmunai in the south, and were expected to reach the town early Monday. The troops are mainly Sinhalese, who make up about 75 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. Tamil rebels say the Sinhalese discriminate in hiring and education against mainly Hindu Tamils, who make up 18 percent of the population. Batticaloa, 135 miles northeast of Colombo, was the first flashpoint of the fighting that erupted two weeks ago, ending a 13-month cease-fire between the government and the militants of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. According to the Defense Ministry statement, nine soldiers died Saturday when Tamil rebels blew up a motorized military patrol near Weli Oya village in the north. Another seven soldiers and 11 rebels died when government troops attempted, but failed, to reach the besieged Kankesanthurai naval base on Jaffna peninsula. On Saturday, troops destroyed five rebel bunkers and cleared land mines as they moved towards Batticaloa, the military officials said. A Tamil reporter in the city described Batticaloa's 200,000 people _ 85 percent Tamil and the rest Moslem _ as ``populating a city waiting to die.'' ``Batticaloa has a whole lot of scars, a burnt Buddhist temple and a police station, and the gutted remains of eight Sinhalese shops. The Sinhalese soldiers are going to be pretty mad when they get here,'' said the reporter, speaking on the condition he was not identified further. On Saturday, President Ranasinghe Premadasa, the architect of the cease-fire forged in May 1989 with the rebels, said he still hoped for a negotiated settlement. Several Tamil militant groups had been fighting for a separate homeland in the northeast since 1983, but most gave up their weapons after a 1987 peace accord. The Tamil Tigers, after a brief acceptance, reneged on the pact and began attacking Indian soldiers. More than 11,000 people have been killed in the seven-year revolt.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Kills Amal Official
DOC.TEXT: A booby-trapped car exploded Sunday near this southern port city, killing the regional security commander of the Syrian-backed Shiite Moslem Amal militia, police said. Three aides of the slain leader were wounded in the blast and rushed to a hospital in Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut, the police said. The car blew up when the commander, Hussein Hijazi, started the ignition, a police spokesman said. The car was parked outside Hijazi's base in Ghaziyeh, three miles south of Sidon, provincial capital of southern Lebanon. No one claimed responsibility for the attack. Amal has been engaged in a three-year power struggle with the pro-Iranian fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God. More than 1,000 people have been killed in intermittent clashes between the two factions in Beirut and southern Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Storm Tavern, Killing 19
DOC.TEXT: Asssailants toting automatic machine guns stormed a tavern near the cocaine trafficking center of Medellin, killing 19 people and wounding at least four, police said Sunday. The massacre occurred Saturday night in Envigado, a Medellin suburb long considered the headquarters of the powerful Medellin cocaine cartel. Twenty armed men entered the tavern, shooting indiscriminately at customers drinking and listening to music, a Medellin police spokesman said in a telephone interview. He said police did not know the motives for the murders, nor who was responsible. All 20 assailants escaped without being caught, the spokesmen said on condition of anonymity. In the past, similar violence in Medellin has been attributed to fighting between rival gangs working for the cocaine barons. In another development, two more policemen were assassinated Saturday in Medellin, bringing to 127 the number of law officers slain in the city so far this year, the police spokesman said. The Medellin drug cartel has commissioned young killers, often riding motorcycles, to shoot policemen throughout the city. It reportedly pays $4,300 for each killing. Medellin, a city of about 3 million, has been placed under virtual army occupation because of bombings and assassinations by drug traffickers. In the past two months, authorities have sent 1,500 new soldiers and policemen to reinforce Medellin's security force. More than 4,000 policemen are patrolling the streets. In August, the government declared war on traffickers following the assassination of anti-drug crusader Luis Carlos Galan. Since then, more than 15 people have been extradited to the United States to face drug charges. In December, police killed the No. 2 leader of the Medellin cartel, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, in a shootout. U.S. officials say cartels in Medellin and the city of Cali are responsible for more than half the cocaine smuggled into the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Group Claims Responsibility For Sea Attack
DOC.TEXT: A Sunni Moslem fundamentalist group on Sunday claimed responsibility for a failed seaborne raid and said its guerrillas had been headed for ``occupied Palestine.'' Police in Tyre, 50 miles south of Beirut, said Israeli warplanes flew over the ancient port city all night, dropping parachute flares that started several fires. A 50-year-old woman was injured and three cars were set ablaze, they said. In apparent retaliation for the aborted raid Saturday night, the Israelis also shelled Tyre. No casualties were reported, but several houses were damaged, a police spokesman said. There were conflicting reports about how many guerrillas and how many boats were involved in the failed raid. Lebanese police said an Israeli patrol vessel spotted two rubber dinghies with outboard motors, each carrying four guerrillas, as they sailed south of Tyre toward Israel. The Israelis opened fire with cannons and machine guns, sinking one of the dinghies and killing three of the guerrillas on board, said a police spokesman in Tyre. The fourth man was reported missing. Israel said only one guerrilla boat was involved with two guerrillas killed. The Islamic Grouping, a Sunni Moslem group based in this provincial capital 25 miles south of Beirut, also said two guerrillas were killed. ``A squad of fighters clashed for more than an hour with the Israeli navy as it was on its way to occupied Palestine,'' the group said in a statement distributed to news organizations in Lebanon. It did not say whether there were others aboard the craft who survived. ``Our fighters shelled one of the enemy's navy boats with rocket-propelled grenades and automatic weapons, causing severe damage and many casualties,'' it added. The Israeli military mentioned no casualties on its side. It said in a statement that the clash at sea occurred off Ras al-Bayada, two miles north of the border and near the headquarters of the U.N peacekeepng force in southern Lebanon. A military spokesman said the attackers were ``headed to destroy targets in Israel.'' It said at least two guerrillas were sighted before troops opened fire, sinking the boat. The army did not identify the guerrillas or say if they belonged to Palestinian or Lebanese groups. On May 30, guerrillas belonging to the Palestine Liberation Front faction of the PLO attempted to attack an Israeli beach south of Tel Aviv. Israeli forces foiled the raid, killing four guerrillas and capturing 12. The attack prompted the United States to suspend its dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization until PLO chief Yasser Arafat condemns the attack and disciplines the leader of the faction, Mohammed Abul Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas.

DOC.HEAD: 1920s Gang Recalls Hard Times, Good Times
LaserPhoto BX4
DOC.TEXT: They came from the across the tracks, and the more they were snubbed, the closer they became. The immigrant kids are retired now, but they still celebrate their exploits as members of the ``Deadline Gang.'' The youthful alliances forged during the 1920s and 1930s will be renewed this Saturday when the gang _ children of immigrants who moved to western Massachusetts in the 1900s _ gets together for a sixth time. The memories come tumbling out when members of the ``Deadline Gang,'' recall growing up in a gritty railroad town when the century was young. For Lester Lamothe, it was picking nuggets of reusable coal from the piles dumped at the railroad yards. For Cy Conner, it was playing ``the whip,'' hanging on to the back of a Model T spinning across a frozen river. For John DeChaine, it was swiping ears of corn to roast on summer bonfires. ``That's all we had. We didn't have anything big, but this was ours,'' said Sam Pompei, balding, 72 years old, but with the mischief of youth glinting behind his thick glasses. ``This goes back to the 1920s and the same feeling toward each other has existed ever since.'' ``Let's be honest, everyone looks at everyone else and sees how old they are,'' Lamothe said. ``Of course, I don't get old.'' Just how the gang got started is hard to determine, members say. ``They never had a meeting, a formal meeting. It just sort of grew out of nothing,'' Pompei recalled. ``When you came through this area, we never bothered anybody, but (we said) `Don't bother our property. Just behave yourselves.''' ``Deadline territory,'' was just a few blocks bounded by a river, railroad tracks, industrial yards and a street. ``This was our back yard. This is where we played and this is where we fought. We've always stuck together,'' said Lamothe, the 68-year-old chairman of the gang's reunions, held sporadically at first, but biennial since 1986. ``Everyone looked at us as `you come from across the tracks,''' he said. ``The more they looked down on us, the more we stayed together.'' Nowadays, shopping strips and fast-food joints have swallowed up the fields where the children used to play. And, somehow, World War II was the time the last of the deadliners grew up. But even as adults living in a world that no longer revolved around the railroad and the local ice rink, the group held onto its past. Now that retirement has freed their afternoons, deadliners still living in their hometown can often be found at the Dante Club, a social club housed in what used to be the neighborhood elementary school. Out come the scrapbooks and the faded black-and-white photographs as new life is breathed into the decades-old memories. ``That one's me,'' a white-haired Flora Senk says, pointing to a 1927 picture of children lined up against the wall, shirts stiff with starch. ``Look at those long stockings,'' she says with a laugh, pointing to the cloth-swathed legs of the dark-eyed girl she once was. Other photographs celebrate the exploits of the grown-up gang. Pete Bessone played hockey with the Detroit Red Wings. The Zucchini brothers, Mario and Babe, played for the pre-World War II Italian Olympic ice hockey team. And there is 1943 Heisman Trophy winner Angelo Bertelli, who now lives in Clifton, N.J., but plans to be on hand for the reunion. ``There was a closeness,'' Bertelli recalled. ``We were all first-generation Italians, or most of us. Our parents, not too many of them spoke good English. (But) it was a beautiful existence. None of us was hungry.'' The reunions started in 1939, when gang members decided to get together one last time as war threatened. That session and two more reunions didn't include women. But in 1986, the women insisted on inclusion. Two years ago, about 500 people showed up and this year the rules have been amended to allow the children of members to attend. Bertelli said he wouldn't miss the chance to see his old friends. For the Heisman Trophy winner, the Deadline Gang comes down to one thing. ``I think of my youth,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Might Find Some Familiar Problems in Washington
With AM-Mandela Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Rampant unemployment. Racial division. Poverty. Nelson Mandela needn't look far in Washington to find some of the same troubles that afflict his homeland. Tourists stroll the manicured Mall and the pristine Capitol grounds. But just a stone's throw away, the city's black community struggles. Many of Washington's problems can be laid at the altar of a flourishing drug trade. ``A Nelson Mandela, a Jesse Jackson or any other leader is not going to change it,'' says Gary Burke, a street vendor in the predominantly black southeast section of the city. ``Talk alone is not going to do it. ... It's around me every day and it affects us deeply.'' More than 400 people were murdered in the nation's capital in 1989, and another 200 were slain in the first half of 1990 _ more than half of the deaths blamed on drugs. During Mandela's visit, Mayor Marion Barry will be spending his days in court _ standing trial on drug and perjury charges. The city's infant mortality rate rose to an alarming 23.2 deaths per 1,000 live births in 1988, more than double the national average. ``We've been hit by a hurricane that government can't control,'' Patricia Tompkins, chief of the Office of Maternal and Child Health, said. ``There's a tremendous amount of drug abuse among women of childbearing age.'' Many of those babies were born to teen-agers. Of the 10,514 births recorded in 1988, 1,765 were born to girls ages 15-19. Local youth employment programs have helped slash the teen jobless rate by half in recent years, but it still stood at 20 percent in 1988. Mandela is not scheduled to see Washington's disadvantaged side during his three-day visit. Nonetheless, many Washington blacks share the excitement Mandela has generated since his release from 27 years in South African prisons. ``I think it's wonderful,'' said Von McMeekin, a graphics worker. ``I think he's going to bring more of an understanding of black people toward each other.'' ``Nelson Mandela is a symbol to black Americans of great courage, principle, integrity and sacrifice,'' said Randall Robinson, executive director of the anti-apartheid lobby, TransAfrica. ``This is the most sought-after person of our time.'' Robinson and others said Mandela is an inspiration to Washington blacks, who outnumber whites by more than 2-to-1 but share little in the city's overall affluence.

DOC.HEAD: West European Leaders Meet To Press Ahead With Unity Plan
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the European Community begin a summit meeting Monday divided over Soviet aid and South African sanctions but set to press ahead with plans to achieve political and monetary union by 1993. ``The whole trend is toward unity and coherence and integration, and not the other way about,'' Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey said. He spoke in a radio interview on the eve of the two-day summit in the medieval Dublin Castle. For the first time an East bloc leader, East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maziere, will join the summit as a guest. East Germany is due to become part of the 12-nation trade bloc after German unificiation, expected by the end of the year. Despite reservations by Britain's Margaret Thatcher, the summit appeared certain to agree to begin a conference on political union in December. It would run alongside one on economic and monetary union, with a December 1992 deadline for final conclusions. Mrs. Thatcher is confident that political union will amount to what she terms ``much closer cooperation'' among the 12 nations, rather than grandiose plans for some kind of federal Europe. At an emergency summit in April, the community leaders agreed to strive toward an undefined form of political union, spurred by what they see as the need for stability in the rapidly changing continent. Britain, threatened with being sidelined while the other 11 nations move toward economic union, last week suggested that the community create a new currency, primarily for tourists and businessmen. The banknotes of the European Currency Unit would circulate with the 12 exisiting currencies. The plan is expected to be discussed in Dublin, but it has received a lukewarm response and been dismissed by critics as the creation of a glorified traveler's check. The issue of aid to the Soviet Union was a last-minute addition to the loose agenda after West Germany and France last week called for the swift organization of a major Western aid program to help President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's crumbling economy. West German and French officials will also seek to get the United States and Japan to agree to an aid package at a meeting next month in Houston of the world's leading industrialized nations. Community officials said there was little prospect of any agreement on Soviet aid being reached at the Dublin meeting. Britain, in particular, endorses the U.S. view that the right course is to give technical and other assistance rather than pouring in money to an economy that is potentially rich but grossly mismanaged. On South African sanctions, the summit appeared likely also to refuse to lift measures and agree only on a general experession of support for President F.W. de Klerk's reform measures. Britain has already lifted so-called ``voluntary'' measures, such as discouraging academic contact and trade missions to South Africa. But the community approval is required to end a ban on imports of South African iron, steel and gold coins and new investment agreed in 1986. After the summit, the community's six-month rotating presidency will pass to Italy. The other members of the bloc are West Germany, Britain, France, Denmark, The Netherlands, Spain, Portugal, Greece, Belgium and Luxembourg.

DOC.HEAD: Alderman Pushing For Precedent-Setting Tax on College Tuition
DOC.TEXT: If Alderman Jack Korshak has his way, students at Northwestern University will be first in the nation to pay a tax on tuition. Administrators at Northwestern and other schools nationwide, students and the American Council on Education say such a tax would hurt students and take a swipe at the value of education. The City Council in this Chicago suburb of 75,000 residents has tried before and failed to implement such a tax. Korshak, a 12-year member of the council and a Northwestern graduate, says the move to tax is back because in his view, his alma mater wants something for nothing. ``The stated public attitude of Northwestern is `We don't give you a dime,''' said Korshak. ``If you treat people in a rotten way, sooner or later people are going to react.'' The reaction came in the form of a proposed 0.5 percent tax on tuition, levied against students at Northwestern and three smaller colleges in Evanston _ including two seminaries. Most of Northwestern's nearly 10,500 students are undergraduates who would pay about $68 a year based on next year's annual tuition of $13,725. The tax would raise more than $700,000 a year, said Alderman Marjorie Collens, head of the city council's Budget Policy Committee. The committee passed the tax proposal May 31. Collens, who opposes the plan, said it likely will be introduced to the full council Monday and could be decided on July 9. No other city in the United States has such a tax, according to Sheldon E. Steinbach, vice president and general counsel of the Washington, D.C.-based American Council on Education. The council represents 1,500 colleges and universities nationwide. A tuition tax would be ``very poor public policy,'' he said. Tuition already is high and ``to impose an additional burden on parents is somewhat unconscionable.'' Some other large universities make donations to their host cities, but usually because city property they have had to buy, said Michael Weston, vice president and general counsel at Northwestern. Cornell University pays its host city of Ithaca, N.Y., more than $2 million in contributions, user fees and property taxes on university-owned land not used for educational purposes, said David I. Stewart, Cornell's director of community relations. Yale and Harvard also make lump-sum payments to their host cities. Some University of California campuses reimburse their host cities for services like fire protection and city planning, said Ron Kolb, spokesman for the UC system. ``But it's always been our position that students shouldn't have to shoulder that burden,'' Kolb said. ``We have always felt it's important to keep fees as low as possible, and I think the university would resist a taxation structure,'' he said. Korshak says Northwestern consistently has avoided paying for police and fire protection. But Weston says the university is a good neighbor, bringing an estimated half million visitors a year to the city, adding millions of dollars to the Evanston economy, and providing cultural advantages often used by city residents. The university also has its own police force, handling most campus calls, he said. ``What this tells the nation and the world about Evanston is really unhealthy _ the notion that education should somehow be subject to tax'' like liquor or cigarettes, Weston said. ``Education may be addictive, but it's clearly a beneficial addiction.'' Lee Ellis, another Northwestern vice president, testified at the committee's hearing that the school pays nearly $1 million a year in utility taxes, permit costs and fees, while students spend $10 million a year and the university spends $7 million a year in the city. But Korshak calls the campus a money machine because he says its annual budget dwarfs the city budget of $77.6 million. Northwestern's operating budget this year is $610 million, said Ken Wildes, director of university relations. ``There's no question that Northwestern is a bigger operation than the city of Evanston,'' Wildes said. ``It doesn't mean we're flush with funds as he implies.'' Some students also object. ``I really think it's absurd that they're trying to tax the students,'' said Paul Murphy, 20, a junior from Syosset, N.Y. Dave Hursey, 23, manager of a Chess-King men's clothing store near campus, said the campus contributes enough. ``If it wasn't for the college, I don't know if Evanston would have much to put it on the map,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: More Blacks Receiving Permission To Live In White Neighborhoods
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government has begun to routinely issue permits to non-whites applying to live in ``whites-only'' neighborhoods, a leading newspaper reported Sunday. President F.W. de Klerk has said that in 1991 the government will amend the law segregating residential areas by race. But a growing number of blacks, Indians and people of mixed-race are seeking and receiving official permission to move to white neighborhoods even before Parliament changes the law, The Sunday Star of Johannesburg said. The newspaper said that when the government received an individual request by a non-white to live in white area, approval often was sent in less than 24 hours. ``As yet I have not had a permit refused,'' one unidentified real estate agent told The Sunday Star. The report gave no indication of how many applications have been approved in recent weeks or months. Government offices were closed Sunday and officials could not be reached for comment. The Group Areas Act, passed in 1950, segregates South African residential areas by race and is considered one of the pillars of apartheid. However, tens of thousands of blacks in recent years have moved illegally into inner-city neighborhoods officially reserved for whites. A far smaller number has applied for and received permission. The government has largely stopped prosecuting alleged violations of the Group Areas Act, although dozens of bureaucrats are assigned to enforce the measure. Last week prosecutors dropped 11 cases against 30 people. The government also has opened four small neighborhoods to all races. De Klerk wants to amend the Group Areas Act but has said he opposes its repeal. He has not spelled out a new plan, but has said the new law must be supported by a majority of South Africans. There is a surplus of housing for the 5 million whites in South Africa, but blacks face a critical shortage. Several million of the country's 28 million blacks live in squatter shacks.

DOC.HEAD: Family Saved Energy, Recited Bible Verses During 5 Days in Cave
DOC.TEXT: A man and his two sons lost in a cave for five days without food or water survived by sitting quietly to save energy and reciting Bible scriptures to remain hopeful, the father said Sunday. ``Toward the end, we figured we were going to die,'' Gary Lutes said. ``We were happy it would be all three of us together and not just one. We figured that was better than continuing on like that.'' Lutes, 37, a Tampa, Fla., land surveyor, and sons Gary Jr., 13, and Timothy, 9, were rescued from a West Virginia cave Saturday, state police said. They had been lost since Monday. They were taken to Rockingham Memorial Hospital in Harrisonburg, Va., where they were listed in stable condition Sunday. The search did not begin until Friday. Father and sons endured bats, dehydration and hallucinations during the wait for rescuers that began soon after their lamps went out while they explored a side trail, Lutes said. ``If it had gone on another day, it would've been a different outcome,'' Lutes said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press from his hospital bed. ``For the first few days, I thought we would be rescued,'' he said. ``After the fifth day, I was really beginning to wonder.'' Lutes, a member of the National Speleological Society, said it was the first time he had gotten lost in 20 years of cave adventuring. He and his sons were exploring New Trout Cave in Pendleton County in eastern West Virginia, about 200 miles west of Washington, D.C. The trouble began when Lutes put down his pack to squeeze through a small opening, intending to retrieve the pack on his way out. When their lamps later went out, he and his sons couldn't find the opening or the pack, which held food, water and extra flashlights. ``When the light started going out, I knew there was a serious problem. (The boys) got upset because they saw the look in my face, but it was basically calm from then on,'' Lutes said. ``I knew if there was panic or terror we'd be nowhere. We wouldn't have made it unless we were sitting and being calm,'' he said. They took turns keeping watch. They recited psalms and prayed they would be rescued, Lutes said. The search began after relatives in Powhatan, Va., contacted police when the Luteses missed a meeting, police said. About 25 experienced cave rescuers from Virginia, West Virginia and Maryland helped police search. Using Lutes' parked car as a starting point, they began combing three sets of caves Friday morning. They found the pack shortly after 12:30 a.m. Saturday and reached the Luteses about 90 minutes later, about a half-mile into a cave, said state Trooper R.D. Gillespie in Franklin. The three were caked in dirt and parched, but otherwise were in remarkably good condition, he said. ``They were thirsty and just jubilant to see the light of day, even though it was night,'' Gillespie said. Barry Chute, a National Speleological Society member from Burtonsville, Md., who led the rescue effort, said the Luteses behaved smartly. ``If you get lost and lose your light sources, you can't go anywhere in a cave,'' he said. ``You can't grope your way out. You'd just go in circles. Lutes, who with his sons was being treated for dehydration and exhaustion, said he plans to give up caves. ``When I was down in there, it sure made things seem insignificant, things I thought were important before. I thought to myself if I ever get out of this, what do those things mean? Job, pressure, whether I get the lawn mowed ... things like that. ``I prayed so hard I'd be given a second chance, and it came through.''

DOC.HEAD: Navy Finds Last Two Missing Crewmen From Helicopter Crash
DOC.TEXT: Searchers have found the bodies of all four victims of last week's Navy helicopter crash off the Virginia coast, a Navy spokesman said. The bodies of Lt. Jane T. Paradeis, 26, of Rice, Minn. and Lt. j.g. Jason K. Skubi, 24, of Sandpoint, Idaho, were found Saturday night, said Lt. Russ Greer, a spokesman for the Atlantic Fleet Naval Air Force. Searchers also found additional pieces of the CH-46 Sea Knight helicopter, which went down at 12:50 p.m. Friday about 6{ miles off Virginia Beach, said Lt. Russ Greer, a spokesman for the Atlantic Fleet Naval Air Force. The bodies of Petty Officer 1st Class Norman H. Geisel, 29, of Saint Mary's, Md., and Airman John W. Burkhardt Jr., 21, of Boylston, Mass., were found earlier Saturday, Greer said. The Norfolk-based helicopter was flying from the Norfolk Naval Air Station to the USS Detroit, a combat support ship, when it went down within sight of the ship. The 89-foot-long, twin-engine Sea Knight is used by the Navy to resupply ships at sea. It can carry loads of 6,000 pounds at speeds of 165 mph. The Navy and Marine Corps fleet of 340 Sea Knights was grounded twice in May because of mechanical problems in the helicopter's rear transmission and forward rotor. The suspect parts were replaced before the helicopters were put back in service. There is no indication the crash was related to those problems, Greer said, and the cause of the crash is under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: First Three `Wilding' Defendants in Jogger Rape Go On Trial
DOC.TEXT: The victim is known only as the ``Central Park jogger'' and she cannot remember the crime. But her gang rape and beating will be relived when three teen-agers go on trial Monday for the so-called ``wilding'' attack. Antron McCray, 15, and Raymond Santana and Yusef Salaam, both 16, are charged with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot in the April 19, 1989, attack. They are being tried as adults. Three other youths face trial later for their alleged roles in the crime that prosecutors say was committed by a gang out for a night of violence in Central Park. The teens allegedly told police they were out ``wilding'' _ a slang term for attacking anyone who wandered across their path. The victim, a Wall Street investment banker, was raped, beaten and smashed in the head with a rock. She nearly bled to death. She suffered brain damage in the assault, cannot remember the attack or identify her assailants and is considered unlikely to testify. Her identity has not been publicized because of the nature of the crime. But despite her injuries, she has recovered. After emerging from a coma and undergoing treatment at a Connecticut rehabilitation hospital, she returned to work at Salomon Brothers Inc., where she recently was named a vice president. Doctors have called her recovery little short of miraculous. The woman, now 29, was out for her nightly jog in the park when she was attacked shortly before 10 p.m. Several other people were attacked earlier in the park by the roving gang. Lawyers for both sides maintain that race has nothing to do with the case, but because the victim is a successful young white woman and her alleged attackers are inner-city blacks, attention has been focused on the race and class of the prospective jurors. Jury selection began June 13. The jurors ultimately selected to hear an estimated six to eight weeks of testimony include blacks, whites, Hispanics and one Asian.

DOC.HEAD: Hijacker Forces Soviet Airliner to Finland, Surrenders
LaserPhoto HEL1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `The aircraft...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with plane returning to Soviet Union. Pick up 15th pvs, `On Tuesday...' ^By MATTI HUUHTANEN
DOC.TEXT: A young Soviet hijacker claiming to have a bomb in his briefcase forced a Soviet domestic airliner to land in Finland on Sunday, then surrendered to police, airport officials said. The 71 other passengers and six crew were released unharmed, and police found no explosives or arms aboard the airliner, said Erkki Lepola, head of air traffic controllers at Helsinki airport. It was the second hijacking of a Soviet aircraft to Finland in less than a week, and the third to Scandinavia in two weeks. Finnish authorities said they were concerned and would raise the issue with Moscow. The plane, a Tupolev 134, was on an internal flight from Tallinn, Estonia's capital, to Lvov in the Ukraine. The hijacker, a 21-year-old Russian, asked for political asylum in Finland. He refused to explain his motive before speaking to a lawyer. Police earlier said the hijacker had asked for political asylum in the United States. A Soviet civil aviation official in Moscow identified the hijacker as M. Varfolomeyev. Finnish authorities refused to confirm his identity because of his asylum request. Soviet authorities have asked for his extradition. Witnesses said Varfolomeyev took control of the plane five minutes after takeoff from Tallinn, and demanded that the crew divert the flight to Stockholm, Sweden. ``About five minutes after takeoff he went to the toilet with his briefcase, then to an air hostess, so I thought he was sick,'' said Vladimir Vager, a passenger who sat next to the hijacker. ``When he came back to his seat he said to us, `All of you remain seated and obey me,' and he said he had a bomb in his briefcase,'' Vager told The Associated Press. He said everyone on the plane remained calm. After conferring with the rest of the crew, the copilot told the hijacker the plane did not have enough fuel to reach Stockholm. Varfolomeyev agreed to fly to Helsinki, where the plane landed Sunday morning. ``When we had landed police came on board with an interpreter and took the hijacker off the plane,'' said Vager. The briefcase and hand luggage were put on the runway and examined with the help of dogs, while the plane was searched for explosives. None was found. The aircraft left later for the Soviet Union, TV news in Helsinki reported. On Tuesday, another Soviet airplane was diverted to Helsinki but had difficulty communicating with the Finns. Tass, the Soviet news agency, reported that the crew needed the help of the pilot of a West German light plane bound for Helsinki. The 20-year-old hijacker of Tuesday's flight, who was identified as Oleg Kozlov, is in police custody in Helsinki. Kozlov also asked for political asylum after surrendering to Finnish authorities. He told police his intention was to reach the United States. Finland, which has traditionally close ties with the Soviet Union, has granted asylum to a Soviet citizen only once before since World War II, in 1973. Officials refuse to discuss that case. On June 9, 17-year-old Dimitry Semionov forced a domestic Soviet plane to land in Sweden by threatening the pilot with a dummy hand grenade. All 114 passengers and seven crew were unharmed and Semionov surrendered. Semionov has been arraigned in court but has not asked for political asylum. He said he wanted to leave his home in Byelorussia after a quarrel with his father.

DOC.HEAD: Cameroon Fans Celebrate Soccer Victory
DOC.TEXT: Soccer fans danced until dawn Sunday after Cameroon's historic advance into the World Cup quarterfinals, and support swelled for a campaign to erect a monument to the team's star player. Police said 21 people were hurt in various incidents during the celebrations, and an entire neighborhood was blacked out by a fire that wrecked three houses. But nothing could dampen the joy that swept Yaounde, the capital, after the 2-1 overtime victory over Colombia on Saturday night. The victory made Cameroon the first African team ever to reach the quarterfinals. ``Euphoria was total,'' said one journalist, describing the throngs that flooded sidewalks and cafes for all-night merrymaking. Roger Milla, whose two goals against Colombia raised his tournament total to four, told national TV he dedicated his goals to his two children and to President Paul Biya. Many of the celebrating fans supported a proposal by the state-owned Cameroon Tribune to construct a monument in honor of Milla, 38, who came out of retirement at age 38 to compete in the World Cup. Citizens were urged to contribute even small sums to help raise the needed funds.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Say Protracted Primary Hasn't Hurt
With AM-Michigan Governor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Democrats' campaign to unseat Republican Gov. Kay Orr has taken a detour _ by way of the courtroom to decide a primary election cliffhanger. Unofficial tallies from a recount in May 15's closest-ever Democratic primary election showed Ben Nelson with a 32-vote lead over Bill Hoppner, but the State Board of Canvassers has not certified the results. Last week, the board ordered 23 of the state's 93 counties to count by hand some ballots that machines had read as having no vote in the race. The additional counting was expected to begin this week. But Nelson, an Omaha lawyer, has asked the Nebraska Supreme Court to order the board to certify the results and declare him the primary winner. Hoppner, a former aide to Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., faced a Monday deadline for filing a challenge to the election. The situation has left Mrs. Orr, who has received high disapproval ratings in recent polls, wondering against whom she should campaign. ``Research is difficult,'' acknowledged Scott Matter, Mrs. Orr's campaign manager. ``What do you do, spend your mornings on Hoppner and afternoons on Nelson?'' Recent floods and tornadoes have given Mrs. Orr a chance to be visible in an official capacity statewide. During a flight to view flood-ravaged northeastern Nebraska, Mrs. Orr said Thursday that she was anxiously awaiting the selection of a challenger, but her campaign goes on _ with or without a known opponent. Mrs. Orr's unpopularity is based largely on the perception that she raised taxes. The governor said that taxes were raised inadvertently when Nebraska's income tax structure was adjusted to match federal guidelines. She admitted the mistake nearly a year after it was made and attempted to soothe ruffled property owners by returning $118 million to them through legislation last year. ``She's clearly in a nasty situation,'' said Larry Grisolano, Hoppner campaign manager. ``With her negative (approval) numbers, she's got to be anxious to go on the attack. The time lag is to her detriment,'' he said. The situation has put Mrs. Orr in a difficult position in other ways. To avoid a potential conflict of interest, she excused herself from Wednesday's meeting of the five-member canvass board which she normally chairs. But it has also posed problems for the Democrats. State Democratic Party Chairman Mike Dugan said it has ``slowed fund-raising, but the money hasn't gone anyplace else. It's still there, a gold mine just waiting to be tapped.'' Grisolano said the ``eventual Democratic nominee will have to play a quick catch-up in fund-raising, but a lot of people are ready to give to the candidate.'' Nelson said he hasn't changed his campaign strategy, but ``I'm eager to get it rolling.'' Democrats have viewed 1990 as an opportunity to recapture the governorship. A mid-April poll of 900 Nebraskans by the Omaha World-Herald showed Mrs. Orr's approval rating was 39 percent while her disapproval rating was 51 percent. And in the GOP primary, Omaha businessman Mort Sullivan, who did little campaigning, received 30 percent of the vote. Matter said Sullivan's showing was ``a concern.'' ``But look at Hoppner and Nelson. Each of them only got 27 percent of the vote'' in the seven-man Democratic primary, Matter said. Dugan said that low percentage is not a concern. ``I am very confident that either one of these candidates have the ability to beat Kay Orr,'' he said. Dugan said the primary ``has drawn a lot of attention to the party, but it hasn't harmed us any. It has the governor concerned and the Republicans don't really know which set of advertisements to use.'' The Republicans can draw on the party for campaign support. President Bush has been in Nebraska twice in four months. Vice President Quayle visited once and the past few weeks brought Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., and Bush's Chief of Staff John Sununu to Orr fund-raisers.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan State Team Wins National Concrete Canoe Competition
DOC.TEXT: The ``Rowing Stone,'' entered by Michigan State University, swamped the competition to win the American Society of Civil Engineers' third annual National Concrete Canoe Competition this weekend. The winners beat 19 other schools to win a $5,000 scholarship for the civil engineering department from contest sponsor Master Builders Inc. of Cleveland. The champions took the title Saturday night after the second phase of the competition, which involved races of 100 meters and 200 meters on St. Rita's Lake at the state University of New York, Buffalo. The first phase _ oral and written presentations of the canoe designs _ was held Friday and counted for 60 percent of team points. The University of Maryland finished second to earn a $2,500 scholarship while the University of California, Berkeley, took third and a $1,500 scholarship. The fourth-place finisher, the University of Texas, Austin, and fifth-place finisher, the University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, will receive commemorative plaques. The canoes are judged on design, construction, speed and maneuverability. The contest is designed both to give student engineers a chance to put classroom theories into practice and demonstrate how concrete can be used to construct a floating vessel.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Seattle-dated item on Michael Jackson to UPDATE with attempt to reach Jackson for comment in new 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Neither rain, nor sleet, nor snow, nor dark of night, nor Michael Jackson shall keep the U.S. Postal Service from its appointed rounds. That's what lawyer Thomas Wampold reasoned after trying to serve a summons and other court papers to Jackson. Wampold filed a class-action suit that alleges Jackson was not sick, as he said he was, when he canceled three concerts in Tacoma, and that he therefore committed a breach of contract with 72,000 fans. A telephone call seeking comment from Jackson's publicist Lee Solters in Los Angeles on Sunday was not immediately returned. The suit also names Ticketmaster Corp., which withheld service fees from refunds on tickets sold to the canceled October and November 1988 concerts. Wampold had no luck trying to reach Jackson's attorney in Los Angeles by telephone. So he decided to have a process server go to Jackson's residence. But process server Mark Hamilton was turned away repeatedly by guards at Jackson's Encino and Malibu homes. At Encino, Hamilton was first told Jackson didn't live there, and then was told he was out of town and wouldn't be back for several weeks. Wampold finally asked King County judge Marsha Pechman for an order allowing him to give Jackson legal notice of the case by first-class and certified mail. The judge granted the request. Wampold figures guards may turn away process servers, but nothing stops the U.S. Postal Service.
