DOC.HEAD: `Reverse Archaeologists' Wants Return Of Relics Looted From Ruins
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of relics left by a lost Indian tribe in the ruins of their famed cliff houses were methodically looted before the turn of the century. Now a band of ``reverse archaeologists'' wants to bring them home. Before Congress outlawed the practice in 1905, collecting baskets, pots, tools and other everyday household items from Anasazi Indian ruins was a thrilling romp through history for explorers hired by East Coast collectors. Like the swashbuckling treasure hunter in the ``Indiana Jones'' movies, they took the ancient ruins of a culture that vanished before Europeans reached the New World. Most of the loot eventually found its way into museum display cases. Large collections are housed at the American Museum of Natural History in New York and the Museum of the American Indian in New York, among others. But a group of volunteer researchers is eager to bring them home to the Four Corners area of the Southwest where the Anasazi pioneered farming and built dense communities hundreds of feet high in scenic cliffsides. Julia Johnson, the director of the volunteer Wetherill-Grand Gulch researchers, decried the looting at a recent symposium on the early Anasazis, known as the Basketmakers, in Blanding, Utah. The group wants to reverse the actions of 1890s explorers and return the artifacts to museums as close to the ruins from which they were taken as possible. To help achieve that and to help scientists study the Anasazi, 5,000 pages of documents and 500 photographs have been compiled on the museum artifacts to trace their origins. Since many of the early-day explorers kept meticulous diaries, ``it's possible in some cases to identify exactly which hole something came out of,'' said Fred Blackburn, a biologist who joined the ``reverse archaeologists.'' Blackburn, 40, and his colleagues crawl through Grand Gulch in Utah, about 100 miles west of Cortez, searching for signatures the explorers carved into cliff walls. By matching the individual artifacts on display in Eastern museums with the diaries, Blackburn's group can supply a research base for scientists studying the Basketmaker era of the Anasazi, he said. The ruins were virtually cleared out and their treasures carted off by the time Congress forbade the practice in 1905, Blackburn said. ``And the expeditions weren't real researchers,'' said Blackburn, whose wife, Victoria Atkins, is an archaeologist. ``There's so much we don't know about the Basketmakers.'' The Basketmaker Anasazis lived in the area from about the time of Christ until the year 700, Blackburn said. They are believed to be the farming pioneers of the tribe that built a thriving civiliation in the famous cliff houses of Mesa Verde National Park. Their Pueblo Anasazi descendants disappeared from the area, apparently driven by a long drought, in about 1300. ``We're putting this together so researchers can go back and find out what the origins of these people were, their customs, where they came from and where they went,'' Blackburn said. He started with the diary of Charles Cary Graham, who with Charles McLoyd began excavating Grand Gulch in 1890. The pair met Richard Wetherill and Charlie Mason just as the latter two were riding out after discovering the landmark Balcony House at Mesa Verde. Wetherill, a nearby rancher and amateur archaeologist, hired Graham and McLoyd to bring artifacts from Grand Gulch to the local historical society. The collection later ended up at the Field Museum in Chicago. As news of the rich ruins spread, other expeditions followed, explorers erasing clues to the mysterious Anasazi's past in their diligence to gather prized artifacts. One likely site for any relics returned to the region would be the Anasazi Heritage Center in Dolores, a town north of Cortez. Initial efforts will try to arrange artifact loans, with the eventual goal of establishing permanent exhibits, volunteers said. Fund-raising is under way to pay for lobbying visits to museums that house large Anasazi collections. Blackburn, who specializes in studies of Bighorn sheep, says his strong ties to the Four Corners area prompted his ``reverse archaeology'' work. He's especially fascinated with evidence of the Anasazis ability to co-exist with the sheep that used to roam the area in large numbers. The fledgling ``reverse archaeolgist'' movement _ looking for artifacts in museums to bring them back to historic sites, rather than the other way around _could provide clues to true archaeologists enabling them to unravel the mystery surrounding the demise of the Anasazi, he said. ``Archaeology is really pretty new here in southwest Colorado,'' he said. ``And there hasn't been much done on the Basketmakers. ``There are a lot of parallels between the Anasazi and what we have today. Overpopulation and drought were a major problem for them and many archaeologists think that's what drove them out of here. Overpopulation and drought are big problems for us, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Ilya Frank, Soviet Scientist and Nobel Laureate, Dead at 81
DOC.TEXT: Ilya M. Frank, a scientist who won the Nobel Physics Prize in 1958 for his work in neutron physics, has died, Soviet television reported Sunday. He was 81. The evening newscast ``Vremya'' said Frank died Friday. It did not report the cause of death or give funeral arrangements or a list of survivors. Frank was praised as an ``outstanding Soviet physicist'' who made ``substantial contribution to nuclear physics.'' ``Soviet science suffered a great loss,'' the announcer said as a photograph of Frank appeared on the TV screen. The obituary was signed by Communist Party and government officials, as well as fellow scientists. Frank was born on Oct. 23, 1908 in Leningrad and graduated from Moscow University in 1928. He worked at the Leningrad Optical Institute, the Lebedev Institute of Physics. In 1944, he became a professor at Moscow University and in 1957, was put in charge of the university lab. Frank shared the Nobel Physics Prize in 1958 with two other Soviets, Pavel Cherenkov and Igor Y. Tamm. He also received the Soviet Union's Lenin Prize. The scientist was a specialist in physical optics and nuclear physics who, along with Tamm, explained the nature of and developed a theory on neutron physics.

DOC.HEAD: Champs-Elysees Turned Into Wheat Field
LaserPhoto PAR2,4
DOC.TEXT: The Champs-Elysees, the most famous street in Paris, was transformed into a giant field of golden wheat Sunday during an eye-catching promotion for French agriculture. An army of 1,500 farmers laid sections of turf holding 3,600 tons of wheat across a large stretch of the avenue starting at the Arc de Triomphe, then mobilized a fleet of tractors to harvest it. Police estimated that more than 300,000 Parisians and tourists gathered behind barricades along the avenue to glimpse and photograph the unique spectacle. Many clasped shocks of wheat in their hands, others purchased small plastic periscopes for $5.40 in order to see over the throng. The field covered almost five acres. ``The Big Harvest'' was sponsored by the National Center For Young Farmers, at the cost of $3.6 million to focus public attention on the positive aspects of farming. Farmers from all member countries of the European Economic Community participated in the celebrations.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Gives Exiles Some Hope of Returning Home
With AM-Mandela Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT that ANC officials trying to arrange Mandela meeting with exiles. Top prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Nomonde Ngudo and Dr. Naomi Baumslag share a dream that might have been impossible to have only a few months ago. Ngudo, a black labor relations expert, and Baumslag, a white pediatrician, want to return to their native South Africa in the near future and maintain the friendship that has developed since they've been living in the nation's capital. For both women, Nelson Mandela's trip to the United States has rekindled hopes that began when South African President F.W. de Klerk agreed that reforms are needed and released the black nationalist leader from prison after 27 years. African National Congress officials were trying to arrange a meeting between some of the area's South African exiles and Mandela following his arrival in Washington on Sunday. ``I am hoping with this Mandela visit, new channels will be opened up to go back home,'' Ngudo said in an interview. ``I am really excited. He (Mandela) embodies all of our anticipations totally.'' Baumslag also bubbled with excitement in a separate interview. ``My heart cries for the country, although my feet are here,'' she said. ``I'm glad it (movement towards change) happened in my lifetime so I could see it.'' The women say their feelings echo the sentiments of nearly all of the estimated 500 to 750 South Africans living in the Washington area. ``My main concern is if we're all going to be absorbed,'' Baumslag said of the desire of many to return home. She pointed to the slow efforts of the white-ruled government to make room for the many South Africans who want to return to their homeland to help put into place the many needed reforms. Baumslag said she also is ``very nervous'' about the reluctance of the United States to provide South Africa with needed resources that are absolutely necessary for changes. Ngudo, who lived in Queenstown, South Africa, said she came to America in 1983 to attend Indiana University of Pennsylvania. After completing the two-year labor relations program, she worked with the United Mine Workers Union. For political reasons, Ngudo refused to discuss her family back in South Africa and why she had not been able to return home. But she stressed her work with the union here has had positive impact in South Africa, where many blacks work in the gold mines. Baumslag and her husband, Dr. Ralph E. Yodaiken, also a South African native, left the country because they could no longer tolerate the poor treatment of the blacks. As physicians working in many of the segregated black townships, they said they constantly were faced with conditions they felt compelled to reveal to the public. ``We were treating preventable conditions that only the blacks were exposed to, such as diarrhea, malnutrition, polio and rheumatic fever,'' said Baumslag. ``We had to choose either to stay there and risk going to jail'' because of the compulsion to buck the apartheid system ``or leave and try to do things from the outside.'' Since coming to America, Baumslag said she and her husband ``have been able to work with others, help with meetings, make ourselves available as resources and help with students. It's almost like a little family.''

DOC.HEAD: When Times Get Tough, Shadyside Looks After its Own
DOC.TEXT: People in this once-thriving mining town say they've never turned to strangers when times got tough, and they're not going to start now. Residents who lost homes and loved ones when a heavy storm sent a wall of water crashing down from the Appalachian foothills are skeptical about help from the government and outside charities, said Mead Township Trustee Gregg Warren. ``People in this town take care of their own. They've always been leery of outsiders,'' said Warren, whose village of 4,300 has lost at least 23 lives and scores of homes and businesses from a flash flood June 14. Ten people are missing. ``There was plenty of food, clothing and volunteerism here before any of these outside organizations came in,'' he said. ``The local TV stations have raised a quarter of a million dollars around here, banks have put up thousands of dollars, contractors have donated the equipment and labor.'' Adversity is no stranger to Shadyside, where the slumping steel and coal industries idled many residents who once earned good wages, and forced others to leave in search of work. ``When the coal industry left, that was the roughest thing that happened to this valley. These people have been beaten down, and now this flood just beats them down even further,'' Warren said. The area's 6.8 percent unemployment figure is misleading because it does not account for people who have been unemployed so long they've exhausted their unemployment benefits, Warren said. Residents know that sooner or later, the government disaster relief agencies, the American Red Cross and others will go home and they will again be alone to deal with their grief and hardship. ``If people in this valley get their lives put back together, it's other people right here who are going to help them get it done, not nobody from Columbus, not nobody from Washington or nowhere else,'' said Ben Otto, whose house along Pipe Creek was severely damaged by the flooding. Robert Henry, the Shadyside Local School District superintendent, said the community would unite to rebuild just as it does to grieve. ``It's a chance for people to pull even closer together,'' Henry said as about 900 people gathered last week at the high school football field for a memorial service for the dead and missing. ``We've got to go from where we are and start to rebuild in our community. The people of Shadyside have always responded that way.'' Residents have not refused government help. A Federal Emergency Management Agency disaster aid center here has received about 350 applications from people who sustained flood damage, said Gene Neiditch, who manages the center. Outsiders also have come in large numbers to volunteer their services, many from hundreds of miles away. Tommy Hause said he and his cousin, Chris Hause, drove in from Mobile, Ala., after reading about the flood. ``Ten years ago, we had a hurricane _ Hurricane Frederick _ hit our state. We had an 11-acre farm, and it was wiped completely out. People from Ohio were the first to volunteer to help us. A group came in from Springfield, Ohio, and stayed at our place 2{ weeks, doing whatever they could. ``I was on vacation, and I said `Well, maybe I ought to be up there,''' said Tommy Hause, 30, who owns an auto parts store in Mobile. People are tired of the reporters and the Ohio National Guard troops who have swarmed into town, said Raymond Ponzo, the school band director. ``People are feeling overwhelmed. We're such a small town. Kids around here are thrilled when the man from the local paper aims a camera at them. Now, they're seeing themselves on evening network news,'' Ponzo said. Warren said townspeople need to be left alone now to deal with their emotions. ``I realized after I went to the first of these funerals that it's more important to be with our own than showing some reporter around,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Distaste For AIDS Patients Turns Doctors Away From HIV Treatment
With AM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Molly Cooke happened to be a physician at San Francisco General Hospital in the eye of the AIDS storm when the epidemic blew in a decade ago. And if she had it to do over again, she would. But some of the 1,045 residents she and other researchers interviewed at 41 internal medicine programs across the nation are so fearful of contracting the deadly virus and so prejudiced against the groups of people primarily infected that they want nothing to do with AIDS treatment. ``The residents' intention to care for HIV-infected people was low by all measures,'' Cooke said. ``Some residents would not treat to save a life in the face of any seroconversion risk, and only 17 percent of the residents (indicated) a strong intent to accommodate HIV-infected people in practice.'' Distaste for the groups of people disproportionately affected by the disease was the one factor that distinguished doctors who had no plans to treat HIV and those who did, Cooke said on Saturday in her report to the Sixth International Conference on AIDS. Some 65 percent of those surveyed agreed with the statement, ``Most IV drug-using patients with AIDS have brought the disease on themselves.'' Forty-six percent agreed with the same statement when the phrase ``gay patients'' was substituted, and 35 percent agreed when ``minority patients'' filled the blank. Eighty percent of the residents thought that treating AIDS was difficult, and more than half were insecure about their ability to offer proper social support. One-quarter believed caring for AIDS patients was unpleasant because they always die. ``What's happening is everybody's scared, and there are some people who have, say, a high sense of professional duty. They say, `I may be scared, but this is what doctors do,''' Cooke said. ``Other people have a low sense of professional duty or are very prejudiced. They say, `These people are not worth me dealing with all this fear about. So I'm going to take myself somewhere else where I don't have to feel this anxiety all the time.''' Cooke said more than half the residents believed that HIV will prove to be transmissible in ways now believed to be safe, and two-thirds said they were afraid of being infected on the job. Thirty-six percent said their practices wouldn't be set up to accommodate HIV-infected patients. ``There's a myth that I ran into all the time in the mid-'80s when I would go out and talk to doctors in other hospitals about what we were doing,'' she said. ``And what people would say was, `You can do that because somehow at San Francisco General, you're different. But it scares us too much.''' For years, she would reply, ``You shouldn't be scared. There's nothing to be scared about.'' She finally decided that wasn't true. ``I learned to say, `It's very scary,''' Cooke said. ``The point is not whether you're scared. The point is what you do next.'' Cooke said the researchers plan to follow the residents and find out what they actually do when their training is done. ``People who are HIV-infected already have to deal with a number of obstacles to getting care,'' Cooke said. ``There's discrimination. The treatments are expensive. The HIV-infected patients in the second wave have enormous social problems in their lives that are impediments to care. ``And I think the unwillingness of physicians may be added to that list.''

DOC.HEAD: Road Tour Kicks Off Corvette Convention
DOC.TEXT: From the 700 Corvettes in the 20-mile road tour to the 200 radio-controlled models in their own road race, there was something for every Corvette fan at the Bloomington Gold-Corvettes USA show. There's also the coveted Bloomington Gold certificate for the Chevrolet two-seaters preserved in or restored to 95 percent of the showroom condition. And there's a classification for ``Survivors,'' Corvettes at least 20 years old that have been largely unrestored but preserved well enough to serve as models for those doing restoration. In excellent condition, a Corvette built between 1963 and 1967 could fetch up to $100,000, says David Burroughs, president of the show. Some custom-built racing models go even higher. Five Grand Sport Corvettes produced in 1963 exclusively for racing are worth up to $1 million, Burroughs says. Next on the most-valuable list would be the L88 Corvette, says Burroughs. Produced from 1967 to 1969, and also built for racing, L88s sell for $100,000 to $500,000. Only about 200 of the cars were built. The demand for Corvettes is changing, though, Burroughs says. The 'Vettes of the 1950s are popular with people who grew up then, but as baby boomers become able to invest in the cars, the 1963-67 models are becoming more popular. About 35,000 people and as many as 5,000 Corvettes were expected for this year's show, which concluded Sunday with judging and the radio-controlled finals.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Rally at White House for Child Care Legislation
DOC.TEXT: Several hundred adults and children rallied in a park across the street from the White House on Sunday to protest the slow progress in getting federal child care assistance legislation enacted. ``Working families are weary of campaign promises that vow to help America's families only to see those promises go unfulfilled,'' Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, told the gathering. The rally took on a festive atmosphere as red, green and yellow balloons were distributed to youngsters, many of whom munched on ice cream bars donated for the event. Several clowns and a juggler performed for the youngsters, along with volunteer who told children's stories and sang children's songs. Ms. Edelman said the rally was intended for families to ``have some fun together on a Sunday afternoon,'' but she also focused on the more serious concerns many parents have about inadequate child care. More than half the mothers of children under 2 work outside the home and millions of parents have a hard time getting proper daycare for their children ``yet the men in Congress and in the White House are still dickering about technicalities'' on a child care assistance bill, she said. The House and Senate have agreed on parts of a $1.75 billion child care assistance bill, but differences remain on some elements dealing with tax credits. The rally featured thousands of paper ``chain links'' that had been collected in more than 130 cities in 30 states to dramatize support for child care legislation. Organizers of the rally said they planned in coming weeks to encircle the White House with the paper chain. President Bush was at Camp David in Maryland during the rally in Lafayette Park across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House.

DOC.HEAD: Right to Live off the Land in Alaska at Center of State-Federal Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `Federal land...', to restore dropped word `for.'
DOC.TEXT: For thousands of Alaskans, venturing into the wild to hunt, fish and gather plants for food is as much a routine part of their daily lives as a trip to the supermarket is for most Americans. The right to live off nature's bounty in this wildlife-rich state is at the center of a dispute that has the federal government poised for an unprecedented takeover of game management in most of Alaska next week. The takeover is the result of an Alaska Supreme Court ruling that put state and federal laws governing subsistence hunting and fishing at odds. On Monday, the Alaska Legislature convenes in special session to consider an amendment to the state constitution that would guarantee that rural Alaskans continue to have first crack at fish and game for subsistence uses. Gov. Steve Cowper says the amendment is the only way to avert a permanent federal takeover of game management on the two-thirds of Alaska that is federally owned. In Alaska, subsistence hunting, fishing and gathering is a traditional way of life central to the state's Indian, Aleut and Eskimo cultures. ``It is the means for them to provide food to feed their extended families and their communities,'' said Julie Kitka, president of the Alaska Federation of Natives. ``It's the core of their existence.'' But Indians, Aleuts and Eskimos comprise fewer than half of the estimated 110,000 Alaskans who take part in subsistence activities. In much of Alaska, the absence of stores and roads to the cities makes subsistence hunting and fishing a necessity. Subsistence is defined and protected for Alaskans in state and federal law. In fact, Alaska is the only state that gives subsistence use of fish and game the highest priority when decisions are made about catch limits and seasons. Sport and commercial hunters and fishermen take a back seat. Subsistence and the way it's regulated has been an issue in Alaska since statehood 31 year ago. The state's first subsistence law was enacted in 1978, and there have been repeated legal challenges. Public support for subsistence rights has remained strong, however. An initiative to repeal the subsistence law failed by a wide margin in 1982, and a statewide poll in March showed solid support for the constitutional amendment. The latest dispute began in December when the Alaska Supreme Court ruled that part of a state law that limits subsistence activities to rural residents unconstitutionally discriminates against urbanites. But a federal law, the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act of 1980, requires a rural preference. As a result, five federal land agencies plan to assume game management of Alaska's federal land _ about 180 million acres _ on July 1 to protect the rural subsistence right. The takeover, which doesn't affect management of the state's fisheries, is expected to lead to considerable confusion among hunters as they are faced with differing regulations on Alaska's patchwork of public lands. Federal land mangers said they were taking over control of the wildlife because of the federal requirement for the rural preference. But they said they were doing so only reluctantly because of the complexity of setting hunting seasons, bag limits and the like over such a wide area. ``It's the worst jigsaw you can imagine,'' said Bruce Batten, a spokesman for the federal Fish and Wildlife Service. The court had stayed the ruling's effective date until July 1 to give the state time to find an alternative solution. But thus far, lawmakers have failed to pass a constitutional amendment bill. Some advocate a permit system that would provide subsistence rights only to those who meet certain requirements based on traditional use and need, regardless of where they live. ``It seems to me you lose some people out in the bush and gain some people in the urban areas,'' said Rep. Robin Taylor, R-Wrangell and House minority leader. ``I think it would be kind of wash.'' A group of environmental and sportsmen's groups and individual plaintiffs in the lawsuit that led to the Supreme Court ruling filed another lawsuit Friday, seeking to overturn the federal rural preference. If an amendment is not put to voters in November, it would be two years before the Legislature could get another amendment on the ballot. Cowper fears that if federal game management is allowed to continue past this year, it could expand and become more restrictive. By the weekend, legislative support for a constitutional amendment appeared to be increasing. Cowper, a Democrat, got help from the state's all-Republican congressional delegation when it endorsed his plan Friday. U.S. Sen. Ted Stevens was scheduled to address a joint session of the Legislature on Monday and urge passage of the amendment.

DOC.HEAD: Two Lawyers Trade Lawsuits in Backyard Basketball Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A neighbors' dispute between a pair of lawyers has escalated into a multimillion-dollar war of lawsuits. It began on an afternoon in March 1989. Michael Rubin, 36, a personal injury lawyer, wanted to take a nap. His neighbor Kenneth Schild, 47, a tax lawyer, wanted to play a little basketball with his son before dinner. Schild sayd Rubin sprayed him and his son with a hose when they wouldn't stop playing basketball. Rubin doesn't deny that, but says his nights have become ``haunted by the fear of being suddenly awakened by the obnoxious sounds'' emanating from his neighbor's basketball court. Schild sued after Rubin allegedly warned that he would enter Schild's property if necessary to prevent future basketball games. And Rubin has sued not only Schild and his wife, Gail, but the couple's son and daughter, ages 13 and 11, their psychologists and attorneys. ``It's very unfortunate, but you have someone attacking your kids in the back yard,'' said Schild. He said his lawsuit, which seeks general damages, is to protect his children's right to play safely in their own back yard. Rubin's lawsuit against the Schilds seeks more than $2 million in assorted damages, claiming injury ``in his health, strength, and activity.'' A Superior Court dismissed the lawsuit against the psychologists and attorneys last week and ordered Rubin to pay $1,500 in damages to the lawyers, but Rubin said he'll appeal. Rubin also has filed a product liability lawsuit against the manufacturer of Schild's backyard basketball hoop and has conducted sound tests to determine the noise level of bouncing basketballs. Rubin has obtained a restraining order limiting the Schilds' basketball playing. Schild got one forbidding the Rubins from coming into contact with them or their guests. The Rubins have videotaped the Schilds shooting hoops, court records show. The Schilds have videotaped the Rubins videotaping them. Schild claims in court papers that he has also videotaped Rubin spraying his son with a hose a second time on April 1 this year. Schild says Rubin told his son, ``You play and I'll spray _ you got that?'' Rubin agrees that's what he said. The two have been unable to settle their dispute out of court, although both say they don't need the hassle of the embarrassing legal battle. ``I guess if nothing else, it's a great opportunity for newspapers to make lawyers look silly,'' Rubin said.

DOC.HEAD: Complex Issues Delay Exxon Trial Until April
DOC.TEXT: The criminal trial of Exxon Corp. over the Exxon Valdez oil spill has been scheduled for April 1991, more than a year after the case was filed and more than two years after the tanker ran aground. U.S. District Court Judge Russel Holland said the case is so complicated both sides will need an unusual amount of time to prepare. ``The underlying factual situation is extremely complex, and it is understood by the court to involve massive quantities of documents as well as review of an extensive transcript of a related, earlier trial,'' Holland wrote in an order signed Thursday. Holland was referring to the state trial of Joseph Hazelwood, the captain who was accused, and acquitted, of operating the tanker under the influence of alcohol when it struck Bligh Reef on March 24, 1989. The crippled tanker spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil in Prince William Sound, fouling miles of shoreline and killing many birds, otters and other sea animals. Hazelwood was acquitted of the alcohol charge and a felony criminal mischief count in March following a two-month trial. Jurors found Hazelwood guilty of a single misdemeanor charge, reckless discharge of oil. In the federal indictment against Exxon and Exxon Shipping Co., the government charged the companies with violations of the Clean Water Act, the Refuse Act and the Migratory Bird Act. In addition, the companies are accused of violating the Ports and Waterways Safety Act and the Dangerous Cargo Act by failing to make sure that competent people were in charge of the vessel and by allowing physically and mentally incompetent people to operate the tanker. In other court papers, the government has said the latter charges are connected to Hazelwood's history of alcohol abuse and the limited abilities of seaman Robert Kagan, who was at the helm when the tanker failed to complete a maneuver and struck the reef. Exxon attorneys say the charges against the oil company for the actions of employees of a subsidiary company are unprecedented. In his trial-setting order, Holland agreed, at least in part, saying the case is ``likely to present novel questions of fact and law'' that will demand more time for trial preparations.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Reduced Farming Town To Pile Of Rocks
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: From a distance, this village on Sunday looked like just another pile of rocks found on any hillside in northern Iran. Thursday's devastating earthquake left hardly a building standing in the town and killed many of its 2,000 residents. In a nearby field, army bulldozers dug communal graves, which soldiers filled with hundreds of bodies and, amid an overpowering stench, hurriedly covered them with soil. The graves were shallow ``because we did not expect so many bodies,'' said one army sergeant on condition of anonymity. A few survivors gathered around the graves and many wailed in grief for relatives and friends. The scene in Manjil, a farming and fishing community on the banks of an artificial lake, 125 miles northwest of Tehran, was reminiscent of old photographs of devastation during World War II. Only occasional telephone poles and parts of some buildings were left standing. A large mural portrait of late revolutionary patriarch Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, half his face reduced to rubble, loomed above the remains of a house. Similar scenes of devastation and tales of grief were reported throughout the afflicted region after the quake, which by some accounts killed 50,000 people. The Islamic Republic News Agency quoted a survivor from Ab-bor village in Zanjan province as saying: ``So many people perished under the rubble. The bodies have not been retrieved or buried.'' ``The whole area is stinking because of the decaying corpses which make rescue operations even more difficult,'' the survivor, identified as Ahmad Ali, said. Another survivor, identified only as Soleyman from Kopteh, another village in Zanjan, said: ``Don't ask me how many are dead. Ask how many survived. Only me, my son and a woman from my village. ``My survival was a miracle, because tons and tons of rocks slid from mountain peaks and buried the village and all the villagers, livestock and orchards are under mountains of rock and rubble,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Superintendent Sends Reassuring Letter to Incoming Female Mids
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf: Rear Adm. ..., to add time element.
DOC.TEXT: The head of the U.S. Naval Academy wants new female students to know the institution will not tolerate incidents like the recent handcuffing of a woman to a urinal. Rear Adm. Virgil L. Hill Jr. wrote to incoming female midshipmen ``to extend his personal commitment to the protection of their civil rights here,'' Lt. Cmdr. Mark Van Dyke, academy spokesman, said late last week. The letters, dated June 1, were mailed to the women who on July 3 will begin their military careers at the academy. Van Dyke said the academy this year accepted 136 of 170 female applicants. Male candidates for the Class of 1994 were not sent letters, Van Dyke said. About 1,000 students are in each class. Van Dyke said Hill was concerned about the adverse publicity the academy received with reports of the handcuffing of former second-year Midshipman 2nd Class Gwen Marie Dreyer. Dreyer, 19, resigned in April to protest the punishment meted out to male classmates who dragged her from her room, handcuffed her to the urinal and snapped photos. Two male midshipmen were penalized with loss of leave time and demerits and six others were issued written reprimands. Van Dyke said Hill's letters congratulated the incoming women on being accepted to the academy and explained the circumstances of the Dreyer case, noting that the male midshipmen responsible were ``severely punished.'' ``Hill also indicates in his letter that he did not feel the news coverage accurately conveyed his disgust over what happened, and that the academy will not condone this behavior,'' Van Dyke said. The case triggered national media coverage and Congressional and Navy inquiries into student hazing and sexual harrassment at the academy. Last month the academy toughened its rules so any midshipman found guilty of physical abuse of a plebe will be expelled. Previously midshipmen were expelled for the more narrowly defined hazing. In the Dreyer case, a hearing panel found the male midshipmen had not planned the action they took and it therefore was not hazing. The new rules also call for increased demerits and restrictions for forcing a fellow middie to engage in horseplay.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Rush Across Romanian-Soviet Border
With XBUC1
DOC.TEXT: About 10,000 Romanians, many waving flags and chanting ``Unite, Unite with the Country,'' poured across a bridge into Soviet Moldavia to mark the 50th anniversary of Moscow's annexation of the republic. Smaller groups from Kishinev, the capital of Soviet Moldavia, and other areas crossed into Romania to visit relatives. The Romanians surged across a bridge at Albita into the Soviet republic, despite attempts by border guards to stop them. Several Romanian army helicopters flew over the frontier surveying the tens of thousands of people who crossed at Albita and at other points along the border. Romanian and Soviet border patrols watched the exuberant Romanians, who crossed without passports or visas. No incidents were reported before the crowds returned home. The Soviet Union occupied Bessarabia, then a part of Romania in June, 1940, and annexed it as the Soviet Republic of Moldavia. ``You cannot stop these people. They have the same blood in their veins,'' said a Soviet border official. He was pushed aside by hundreds of Romanians who stormed passed a red line marking the border in the middle of the bridge. Romanians and Moldavians were seen swapping addresses, books and records and heatedly discussing the possiblity of reunification. ``This celebration does not do any good for the USSR, but it does to us because we want to live with our families from the other side in democracy,'' said 24-year old Elena Matarkova. The Popular Front of Moldavia and other official and independent cultural organizations have been growing on both sides of the frontier. On May 6, tens of thousands of Romanians streamed across eight bridges on the Prut River into Soviet Moldavia for their first visit to the republic in more than half a century. Last year, Moldavia restored their language's Latin script, which is virtually identical with the Romanian script. The Soviet Union had imposed the use of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet in Soviet Moldavia. On Saturday, Moldavia's Parliament followed the Baltic states and Russia in approving a declaration of sovereignty, declaring that its laws supersede those of the Soviet Union. Addressing the crowd on the bridge, Ion Hadarcan, president of the Popular Front of Moldavia, said the declaration of sovereignty turned Moldavia ``into a free nation again.'' After several hours the crowds peacefully returned home to their respective sides of the border.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Committed to Socialism Despite Changes Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Cuban President Fidel Castro says he remains committed to socialism, despite the political changes in the Soviet Union and the wave of democracy that has swept Eastern Europe. Castro also said in an interview with media tycoon Ted Turner that the changes in the Soviet Union would not affect its political ties with Cuba. Soviet reforms, said Castro, ``may affect our economic relations, not political relations. If the Soviet Union wants to adopt the U.S. Constitution, we will respect that.'' But capitalist-style reforms will not be coming to Cuba, Castro said. ``As a socialist and as a man that is fully convinced of what socialism means, of what socialism has meant for our country, I cannot agree with that movement in the socialist countries toward capitalism,'' he said. ``We have not renounced any of these possibilities of socialism.'' Castro said the changes in Eastern Europe resulted from complex situations unique to each nation and rejected the idea that the changes were sudden. The interview, taped during Turner's visit to Cuba June 8-10, is to be shown Monday night on his Cable News Network. Turner and Castro have been friends for several years, and in 1982 the Cuban leader appeared in a promotional spot for CNN.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Riot, Wait in Line as Unification Moves Closer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with comment by East German prime minister, SUB 5th graf pvs, `Despite recent...' with 2 grafs of comment by East German prime minister; pickup 6th pvs, `East Germany's...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Germany-Europe, Bjt
LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: East Germans lined up in front of banks on Sunday as they spent an anxious weekend on the threshold of enormous change. Next Sunday, the former Communist country will merge its economy with West Germany, a momentous event that will have an immediate effect on the lives of the nation's 16 million people. Left-wing radicals tried to attack the East Berlin headquarters of a neo-Nazi group Saturday, the latest in a series of extremist clashes in recent months that some officials call a byproduct of the social upheaval under way. Authorities said 21 police officers were badly injured in the rioting, and East German Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel called for tougher laws against extremist acts. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere urged the nation to stay calm and condemned extremist violence as an affront to the peaceful revolt that toppled the former Communist government last fall. ``Right extremist power must not be combated through violent left extremism,'' he said in a statement. ``The basis for the democratization of our land was the peaceful protest of the people. So must it remain.'' East Germany's currency will be changed to West German marks Sunday, which marks the former Socialist nation's official immersion into the free market and a major step toward full unification with West Germany. Banks stayed open all weekend to allow customers to fill out applications to change their savings to West German marks, and thousands of people stood in lines. To keep the powerful West German mark from being weakened by the abrupt expansion of the money supply, East Germans will only be able to convert 2,000 marks _ $1,210 _ of their savings to West marks during the first month of economic union. Some already were receiving checks for that money, which they will be able to cash Sunday. ``We're going to buy a car,'' said Margit Schollain, 32, as she waited with more than a thousand other people in lines that snaked from a bank on East Berlin's Leipziger Street. The mood was a mixture of apprehension and excitement over the economic experiment about to unfold. ``I think it will bring many social problems, and not just unemployment,'' said Jan Falkenstern, 24, as he waited. ``I think the unrest that happened yesterday is part of it.'' The riot in the city's Lichtenberg district followed a demonstration by about 4,000 leftists who were protesting recent attacks by radical rightists on foreigners. The group tried to march on an apartment house where members of the radical right-wing group, National Alternative, lived. However, thousands of police blocked intersections and the protest broke up without incident. Later, police said 400 leftists rampaged through the streets and battled police, who used tear gas, truncheons and water cannons. Four police vans were burned and a small kiosk was plundered. Four people were arrested. Lichtenberg, a working class district where many Vietnamese, Mozambicans and other foreigners live, has become a flashpoint for extremist violence. Diestel said in a statement Sunday the government should ban such radical groups and give the police broader powers to battle extremists. Resentment of foreign workers in East Germany has been growing. The country is expected to face massive unemployment as its former state enterprises compete with more efficient Western companies that already are flooding the country. On Leipziger Street, West Germany's Mayer food chain already has renovated a building just 50 yards from a dowdier looking East German store. The new store is to open its doors next week. ``It is too expensive,'' said Martin Ibold, 31, as he waited in line at the bank across the street. ``I know a lot of these people will take their (West German) marks and buy a lot of things. ``But I have two children and another coming probably this week,'' he said, gesturing to his pregnant wife. ``I just need the money to live and keep up with the prices.''

DOC.HEAD: Search Still On for 9-Year-Old Missing Since Autumn
DOC.TEXT: More than 120 people searched a wilderness area this weekend for the body of a 9-year-old boy who disappeared during a cattle drive last autumn, leaving behind only his wandering horse. Nathan Madsen was last seen heading back toward camp on Oct. 22, 1989. A month later, his horse was found wandering on a rocky crest. More than 120 people from eight counties trudged through Mount Thielsen Wilderness this weekend, but found no sign of the boy. ``We can't do anything for Nathan,'' said Klamath County search and rescue chief Del Sparks. ``But the family needs to know something so they can get their lives organized again.'' The boy's father, Jerry Madsen, said the family would not abandon the search effort even if nothing turned up this weekend. Nathan was the subject of one of the most extensive searches ever conducted in Oregon. Hundreds of searchers culled through the forest and clawed their way up stony slopes until mid-December snows drove them out of the mountains. This weekend's efforts were the first since the spring thaw. Nathan's pony was the only clue. The animal was found a short distance below the 6,400-foot summit of Six Horse Springs Ridge, where tracks and manure indicated he had been in the area, five miles from the nearest road, for two weeks. The tackle was removed, suggesting Nathan might have taken them and huddled somewhere nearby, using his pony's saddle blanket for warmth.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Warned Durenberger in 1986 About Condominium Deal
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 7th graf, ``It wasn't xxx to change phrasing in reference to newspaper
DOC.TEXT: By LARRY MARGASAK=

Sen. Dave Durenberger was cautioned by his attorney in 1986 about accepting government reimbursement for stays in a Minneapolis condominium, according to documents, despite his contention this month that he had no reason to doubt the propriety of the plan. Durenberger, R-Minn., collected $40,055 in per diem payments from the Senate from 1983 to 1989 for staying in the condominium. He was part owner from 1983 to 1987, and says he sold the facility in April 1987 _ a deal called a sham by the special counsel for the Senate Ethics Committee. The propriety of Durenberger accepting reimbursement for staying in the condominium _ with a bedroom, bathroom, kitchen and sitting area _ is one of the principal areas of investigation for the Senate panel. After a 15-month investigation of alleged financial irregularities by the 55-year-old Republican, the committee soon will decide whether he willfully violated the rules and deserves punishment. The committee's special counsel, Robert S. Bennett, argued in trial-like hearings June 12 and June 13 that Durenberger misled the Senate. First, Bennett said, Durenberger hid his part ownership of the condominium as he collected reimbursements from 1983-87; and then he engineered a phony sale to the company owned by his former campaign manager to keep the reimbursement money flowing from 1987 to 1989. It wasn't until December 1989 that Durenberger formally sought the Senate's advice on the propriety of the reimbursements, after a story in the Star Tribune newspaper in Minneapolis raised questions. The Rules panel said $11,005 of the reimbursements were improper, and Durenberger repaid the money. The Ethics Committee will determine the legality of the remaining $29,050. Three years before Durenberger asked for a Senate ruling, his personal attorney, Michael C. Mahoney, advised the senator in late 1986 that he ``couldn't find any support'' for the reimbursements the lawmaker had been receiving since 1983. Mahoney recalled the advice in statements to the Ethics Committee, now part of its official record. The documents made public in the Ethics Committee probe also show that seven months after lawyer Mahoney issued his caution, in June 1987, Durenberger confided to friends in a personal letter that he believed he had relied on ``shaky or misleading'' legal advice when he set up the condominium partnership in 1983. In his appearance before the committee June 13, the senator conceded that rules had been broken, but insisted he never intended to commit violations. Durenberger said the ``strains and vulnerabilities'' in his personal life affected his decisions, including heavy education and medical expenses, the loss of his first wife to cancer and the burdens of his current wife, Penny, whose first husband was killed in Vietnam. The senator told the committee that ``all the key decisions'' on the condominium were made by his lawyers. Defense attorney Jim Hamilton argued, ``there was no warning for six years'' that anything was improper. Durenberger spokeswoman Lois West, asked to comment on the documents, responded, ``We aren't going to try to argue our case in the press.'' Durenberger's June 1987 letter was written to a former campaign chairman, Gene Holderness, and former law partner Paul Magnuson, now a U.S. district judge. He wrote: ``For the last five years I have had the benefit of renting my former condominium at 1225 LaSalle from a partnership with (businessman) Roger Scherer. I now discover that my legal advice was either shaky or misleading.'' Bennett, the Ethics Committee lawyer, said Durenberger misled the Senate when he and Scherer each placed a condominium into their joint venture and named it the 703-603 association _ not using the senator's name. Durenberger rented the condominium from the association. Bennett further said that the 1987 sale to the firm headed by Durenberger's ex-campaign manager, Paul Overgaard, was engineered solely to continue the reimbursements. The transaction, documents show, was an oral agreement, and final papers were not signed until October 1989 _ after Overgaard threatened to cancel the deal due to the delays. Durenberger said he bought the condominium in 1979, but when it became too costly in 1983, he placed it in the partnership with Scherer, a former Minnesota state legislator and a businessman. He said he made the deal with Overgaard after Scherer said he was backing out of the partnership. Durenberger said he made the 1983 ownership change because a political adviser told him he could qualify for Senate reimbursements by renting the condominium or staying in a hotel, but not if he owned the residence. In fact, Senate rules are unclear on how ownership affects reimbursements when a senator stays in his home state. In an interview with Ethics Committee lawyers in April 1989, Mahoney stated, ``our advice was we can't confirm nor could we deny'' that Durenberger was correct in his interpretation that the rules allowed the reimbursements. ``We simply couldn't find any support for it.'' In his defense, Durenberger pointed to a legal opinion he was given June 28, 1983, by another lawyer, Randall E. Johnson. Johnson's sworn statement to the committee on June 7 said he advised Durenberger seven years ago that ``under Senate rules, I believed he could claim reimbursement for official business stays at the condominium that he rented from the partnership.''

DOC.HEAD: Church President Released From Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Mormon Church President Ezra Taft Benson was released from a hospital here Sunday after being treated for a bacterial infection. No further information was available on the condition of the 90-year-old church leader, said Don LeFevre, spokesman for the 7.5 million-member church. Benson was admitted to LDS Hospital in serious condition on Wednesday. He was moved out of the intensive care unit Friday and his condition upgraded to fair. Benson, who received an electronic heart pacemaker in 1986, was U.S. agriculture secretary under President Dwight D. Eisenhower. He was named president of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms and Record Low Temperatures Mark Summer's First Weekend
DOC.TEXT: Unseasonably cool weather Sunday chilled out a week's worth of high heat in the Deep South, but the Southwest sizzled for the first weekend of summer. Weatherford, Texas, west of Dallas, got hail as large as tennis balls during the morning, but much of the region got afternoon rainshowers and thunderstorms ranged from central and northeast Texas across eastern Oklahoma. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered from south-central through northeast Kansas, northeast Nebraska, the upper Texas Gulf Coast, southwest Louisiana and parts of Florida. Showers and thunderstorms also extended from eastern Kentucky across Ohio, western and northern Pennsylvania, eastern New York and central New England. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included almost two-thirds of an inch at McAlester, Okla. Cool early morning temperatures snapped a weeklong string of hot days in the lower Mississippi Valley. Low temperature records for the date were: 61 degrees in Little Rock, Ark. (the previous low was 63 in 1926); 64 in Mobile, Ala. (65 in 1893), and 65 in New Orleans (66 in 1965). It was a hot day for eastern New Mexico, western Texas, the Texas Panhandle and southeast Colorado, with temperatures reaching 106 degrees by early afternoon at Roswell, Carlsbad and Tucumcari, New Mexico. Lubbock, Texas, reached 105 degrees, but the state's record highs were 98 degrees in Corpus Christi (97 in 1964), and 105 in Midland and Odessa (104 in 1980). Pueblo, Colo., tied its 1971 record of 104 degrees. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 53 degrees at Mansfield, Ohio, to 109 degrees at Palm Springs, Calif. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states Sunday morning was 36 degrees at Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Del-Vikings Founder Dies at 57
DOC.TEXT: Corinthian ``Kripp'' Johnson, the founder of the 1950s doo-wop quartet the Del-Vikings, has died of cancer. He was 57. Johnson died Friday at his home, said band member Ritzy Lee. Johnson founded the Del-Vikings in 1955 _ the first racially integrated rock 'n' roll group. The four were best known for the hits ``Come Go With Me'' and ``Whispering Bells.'' Lee said the cancer hit Johnson hard in the last few months. ``He knew it was coming because he was very weak,'' Lee said. ``I was lucky to have known him. I owe being in show business to him.'' ``He was a spiritual and religious man,'' said Mili Lilley, manager of the group since 1985. ``He was the heart and soul of the group. He was loved by a lot of people and is certainly going to be missed.'' Elmer Hopper, lead vocalist with the Platters, visited Johnson at a Detroit area hospital earlier this month. ``So sad, so fast,'' Hopper said. ``We worked so many shows with him,'' Hopper said, adding that Johnson told him, ``God was good to me. I had a wonderful life.'' Johnson last performed with the band April 26 in Hollywood, Fla. He is survived by his wife, Johnnie Mae, four sons and four daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Anglican Church of Ireland Ordains First Two Women Priests
DOC.TEXT: The Church of Ireland ordained two women as priests Sunday, joining Anglicans in seven other countries in taking a step resisted by the mother Church of England. The Rt. Rev. Samuel Poyntz, bishop of Down and Connor, ordained Irene Templeton and Kathleen Young in an afternoon ceremony in St. Anne's Cathedral. They became the first women priests in the United Kingdom. Mrs. Templeton, 49, of the Belfast suburb of Dunmurray, is married and has a 5-year-old son. Mrs. Young, 50, of Carrickfergus, is widowed. Four men also were ordained. Both women had previously been ordained deacons, which is the highest post women may hold in the Church of England. Mrs. Young had been a paid curate in Carrickfergus while Mrs. Templeton was unsalaried. The Church of Ireland's General Synod decided May 17 to admit women to the ranks of priests and bishops. It became the seventh Anglican province to ordain women, following the United States, Canada, New Zealand, Brazil, Kenya, and Uganda. The ordinations in Ireland may have a greater impact on the Church of England because priests ordained by the Church of Ireland, like those of the Scottish Episcopal Church and the Church in Wales, are not classified as overseas clergy by the Church of England. At the time of the synod vote, The Irish Times of Dublin said in an editorial that the ordination of women as Anglican priests ``may come to be remembered as one of the landmarks in the liberation of women in Ireland. ... This was a brave vote, which places the Church of Ireland not only at the forefront of liberal thinking in Ireland but at the forefront of liberal thinking in the Anglican Community.'' Earlier this month, the spiritual heead of the Anglican church, Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie, said he expected to see women ordained by the Church of England within a decade. Ecclesia, a newsletter published by a conservative Anglo-Catholic organization in Hull, England, denounced the Church of Ireland as ``a Protestant sect that can no longer claim the allegiance of Catholics.'' According to the Church of England Newspaper, Ecclesia contended that future Irish Anglican ordinations will be invalid.

DOC.HEAD: Children Playing With Lighters Blamed for 280-Acre Brush Fire
DOC.TEXT: A fire that burned more than 280 acres of parched brush near here was started by two children playing with cigarette lighters, officials said Sunday. The fire in Pole Canyon, a dry mountainous area about 50 miles northwest of Los Angeles, was virtually contained and almost under control Sunday afternoon, said Cece Grives, a spokeswoman for the Ventura County Fire Department. No injuries were reported and no structures were threatened by the fire that began Saturday afternoon, she said. Winds in the area were calm Sunday. About 150 firefighters and one water-dropping helicopter remained on the scene Sunday. Witnesses told authorities about the children playing with lighters, said Ms. Grives, who added that no arrests had been made. In Los Angeles, firefighters moved quickly Sunday to douse a two-acre blaze in the Mount Washington area and a small fire in Highland Park. Fire danger throughout California is considered extreme this summer after a four-year drought turned millions of acres of trees and brush into brittle fuel.

DOC.HEAD: At Least Five Killed In Riot Over Marriage Procession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to recast lead, clarifies that wedding procession was near Agra; UPDATES with details on Sunday's clashes, raises death toll, ADDS other details; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Members of Hindu castes clashed for a third day Sunday in a dispute that began over a noisy wedding procession near Agra, site of the world's greatest monument to love. At least five people have died in the fighting, news reports said. Police opened fire several times to control the rioting, which began late Friday, the reports said. One woman was killed and 50 people were injured Sunday in clashes in Akola village near Agra, United News of India said. The news agency said sporadic fighting continued in other nearby villages. The Hindustan Times said four people were killed Friday and Saturday in the fighting and police fire, but the Times of India, quoting witnesses, said six people died during the same period. The reports said about 60 people were injured in the first two days of clashes and that dozens of shops and buses were burned. On Saturday, mobs armed with guns and sticks prevented tourists in Agra from visiting the Taj Mahal, the 17th century white marble mausoleum built by the Mogul emperor Shah Jehan as a tribute to his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal. Police slapped an indefinite curfew on the city, 110 miles south of New Delhi. Authorities extended the area of the curfew on Sunday and said the situation was ``tense.'' The trouble began late Friday in Panwari village outside Agra. Residents objected when thousands of people who were to take part in the wedding tried to walk through their town. The villagers said they didn't want the celebrants in Panwari because the wedding participants were noisy and belonged to a low Hindu caste while the villagers belonged to the relatively high Jat, or farmer, caste. When the revelers shouted insults, villagers who were perched on the walls of their houses hurled stones, the Hindustan Times newspaper said. Fighting spread to at least 10 other nearby villages and some parts of Agra, the Times said. Clashes between various Hindu castes are common in India and claim dozens of lives every year.

DOC.HEAD: World Saxophone Quartet Dazzles Carnegie Hall Crowd
DOC.TEXT: Sometimes programming is the worst enemy of jazz festivals. Take Saturday night's lineup at one concert of the JVC Jazz Festival. The World Saxophone Quartet, a powerhouse jazz outfit, was paired with Steve Reich and his disciples, followers of minimalist music. Talk of an odd couple. In the old days at Newport, the Rhode Island forebear of this annual Big Apple festival, such a pairing would have been laughed off Aquidneck Island. Maybe those in charge thought this kind of eclectic bill would attract a large New York audience. If so, they were wrong. But adding a solid jazz group and deleting the minimalists might have filled the place and created a night worth remembering. Although the program indicated the saxophonists would play the second half, they came on first. They were wise; they didn't have to hang around backstage listening to Reich's futuristic but joyless stuff. The quartet _ Arthur Blythe, Oliver Lake, David Murray, Hamiet Bluiett _ impressed the Carnegie Hall crowd with their skillful playing, their feeling for their music, much of which they've composed themselves. This is no kind of ersatz all-star group, in which each player has a starring role but the group as a whole is only passable.The four saxophonists clearly respect each other and enjoy their collaboration. In solos and together, they explored the saxophone's full range, its hotness and coolness, its chaos and simplicity. And what a pleasure to hear jazz without all the electronics. This is the way jazz should be played, whether in Preservation Hall in New Orleans or in a New York concert hall. Unfortunately, for some in the audience, the World Saxophone Quartet's set lasted only 45 minutes. Steve Reich and his musicians played only two pieces, one of which ran an hour by itself. At the end the listener wondered, what did this New Age music have to do with a jazz festival? The JVC Jazz Festival, sponsored by the Japanese electronics firm, runs in New York through Saturday and then goes to Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: 600,000 Watch Hindu God's Chariot Derail During Festival
DOC.TEXT: A four-story chariot carrying a wooden image of a Hindu god crashed onto a building Sunday, but it didn't dampen the spirits of 600,000 celebrants marking the Lord Jagannath festival, one of Hinduism's biggest. Nobody was injured when the chariot carrying the wooden image slipped off its tracks and crashed into a building. During the observances, Hindus bedecked in flowers chanted and sang, while many surged to touch images of Hindu gods. The festival at Puri, an ancient town on India's east coast about 1,550 miles southeast of New Delhi, has been celebrated for almost 1,000 years. The festival introduces Lord Jagannath, Hinduism's god of the universe, to non-Hindus. But few non-Hindus were on hand Sunday. During the rest of the year, nonbelievers are prohibited from entering Puri's 11th-century Lord Jagannath Temple. It houses the images of the Hindu god, his elder brother Balabhadra and sister Subhadra. These images _ 6{-foot-high wooden statues _ are taken out of the temple during the festival, placed on chariots and rolled around Puri until they reach another temple, where they remain for nine days. Hundreds of devotees had enormous difficulty lifting the statue of Lord Jagannath onto his chariot. Made of solid wood, it weighs several tons. Some said that Jagannath, who legend describes as a willful god, ``didn't want to leave his temple this year.'' The wooden images were placed on the chariots, which stand four stories high atop 14 wheels about eight feet in diameter. The king of Puri, part of India's hereditary aristocracy, arrived on a silver litter led by an elephant. He blessed the chariots and swept the floors with a golden broom. Then the procession started. Thousands of devotees pulled ropes attached to the chariots on the two-mile journey along Puri's Grand Avenue to the other temple. Hindu legend says that pulling a chariot guarantees salvation. After about 100 yards, the chariot of Lord Balabhadra fell off its tracks and crashed into nearby buildings. Eleven of the chariot's wheels were damaged. As night fell, furious efforts were made to repair the wheels of Lord Balabhadra's chariot so it could finish the journey Monday. News reports said that ``every available'' lodging in the city had been filled by pilgrims from all over India. Tourists and worshippers from the United States, Japan and Europe also flocked to the festival.

DOC.HEAD: `Tiara Boom Today' For Princess Di Story Wins Headline Award
DOC.TEXT: A New York Daily News copy editor who crowned a story about the Princess of Wales with ``Tiara Boom Today'' has won the Wuxtry Headlines Award. ``I love what I do. It's hard to find a job where they pay you to write puns,'' said winner Wayman Wong, 31. The award, named for newsboys' garbled cry of ``Extra!'', was announced Saturday at a San Francisco Press Club luncheon sponsored by the International Society for General Semantics. Headlines were judged by a panel of 19 newspaper editors, writers, semanticists and teachers. The Wuxtry for outstanding performance in handling major news went to the Daily News. Last year the paper shared the award with The Houston Post. Ned Crabb, The Wall Street Journal copy editor who puts brief headings atop letters to the editor, received a Wuxtry special recognition award. Another went to Dewey Webb, a writer and editor at the weekly New Times in Phoenix. The Sacramento Bee, San Francisco Chronicle, Seattle Post-Intelligencer and Oregonian received commendations for outstanding copy desk performance. The Standard Times of New Bedford, Mass., received a commendation for outstanding copy desk performance for a newspaper with less than 50,000 circulation.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Overtakes U.S. As World's Biggest Aid Donor
DOC.TEXT: Japan surpassed the United States to become the biggest donor of government aid to the Third World in 1989, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Monday. The achievement could soften criticism that Japan, with its immense financial strength, has not done its share to help developing countries. Japan's total aid effort in 1989 was $9 billion, compared with $7.7 billion for the U.S., the Paris-based organization of industrial democracies said in a report. The U.S. figure represented a decline of 27 percent from 1988, after adjusting for inflation. The decline meant that U.S. aid as a share of gross national product declined from 0.21 percent in 1988 to 0.15 percent last year _ the worst performance among the organization's main aid donor countries. Joseph Wheeler, chairman of the group's Development Assistance Committee, told a news conference Sunday that U.S. aid to the Third World has fallen steadily in recent years. But Wheeler said he expects the U.S. will lift its aid effort to at least $9 billion this year. He said U.S. contributions to multilateral aid institutions should return to normal levels in 1990, and substantial new aid programs in Central America are likely. But this probably won't be enough to enable the U.S. to regain its number one slot, Wheeler said, since Japan plans to spend at least $31 billion on aid over the next three years. Wheeler said government assistance to developing countries from all sources in 1989 totalled $51.3 billion, scarecely changed from the year-earlier figure of $51.7 billion. The total flow, including private funds and export credits, to these countries is estimated at $109 billion, up 4.5 percent from 1988. Wheeler said the aid effort of the international group's 18 richest countries has increased in real terms at an average rate of 2.9 percent a year, or a total of about 33 percent in the past decade. Wheeler said the aid effort of Western industrialized nations in 1989 wasn't affected by assistance to Eastern Europe. Most donor countries have indicated future aid to Eastern Europe won't be diverted from traditional aid recipients, he said. The group said Scandinavian countries continued to provide the most official aid last year as a percentage of GNP, led by Norway with 1.02 percent. The member nations are: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the United States and West Germany. The third biggest donor in dollars, after Japan and the U.S., was France with $5.14 billion followed by West Germany with $4.95 billion.

DOC.HEAD: A `Darryl' From `Newhart' Weds
DOC.TEXT: For years on TV's ``Newhart,'' John Voldstad only grinned when introduced by brother Larry as one of the silent Darryls. But he managed recently to get out the words ``I do'' and wed 20-year-old Kellye Fowler in Gadsden, Ala. Voldstad, 39, who played the chubby, blond Darryl, met Kellye in August when he was playing tennis in a celebrity tournament in Macon, Ga., and she asked him for an autograph. ``She was spelling Kellye with a ye, and I thought, 'Umm, that's very pretty,''' Voldstad says in the July 2 issue of People magazine. Kellye's mom wasn't too keen about the romance and _ not trusting those Hollywood types _ went along on most of the couple's dates. Kellye, who wants to act, appeared on ``Newhart'' as an extra before the show went off the air. But it's love, not a career, she wanted from Voldstad, she says: ``I love John and he loves me, and if you can't see that you must be blind.'' As for their 19-year age difference: ``John's 25 mentally anyway,'' she shrugs.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Aftershock Triggers Landslide in Devastated Area
LaserPhotos TEH1,9 TOK2,3,4,5,6
DOC.TEXT: The most powerful aftershock in three days rocked earthquake-devastated northern Iran on Sunday, triggering a landslide that blocked the road linking this shattered town to the Caspian Sea coast. The casualty toll climbed to 50,000 dead and 200,000 wounded, according to a newspaper close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani. Official radio put the death toll at 48,000. Army mountaineers climbed peaks in the rugged region in an effort to rescue villagers trapped in remote hamlets following Thursday's earthquake, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Tehran radio said 68 relief aircraft had landed at the capital's Mehrabad airport during a 24-hour period. Among them was a cargo jet carrying 84,000 pounds of U.S. aid _ including bandages, antiseptic burn cream, tents and orange slices in syrup _ collected by Americares, a private relief organization based in New Canaan, Conn. It was the first overt U.S. shipment of its kind to be accepted by Iran since the hostage crisis of 1980, when 52 American hostages were held at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran for 444 days. The two nations have no diplomatic ties. In Washington, the State Department said a Red Cross charter flight carrying supplies donated by the U.S. government was scheduled to arrive in Tehran late Sunday. Earlier, the radical newspaper Jomhuri Islami urged that no help be accepted from the United States and other countries whose hands ``are stained with the blood of the Iranian people.'' The Foreign Ministry, however, said that ``due to the magnitude of the disaster'' Iran would accept all such aid. ``Iran accepts the assistance of all foreign countries except Israel and South Africa,'' Tehran radio quoted Deputy Foreign Minister Ali Mohammad Besharati as saying. There were conflicting death tolls. The Tehran Times, the nation's leading English-language newspaper, quoted an unidentified senior relief official as saying 50,000 people died and 200,000 were injured in the quake. He said even that was a conservative estimate because ``the figures are quoted taking account only of those who have been registered officially as dead or wounded.'' Many victims were not counted, he said. In Geneva, senior U.N. relief official M'hamed Essaafi also estimated the toll would reach 50,000 dead and 200,000 wounded. Tehran radio put the toll late Sunday at 48,000 killed and 100,000 injured. The stench of decomposing bodies hung over Rudbar, a town of 100,000 people. Rescuers aided by police dogs pulled bodies from the rubble. A team of 205 French rescue workers arrived in the region with 18 search dogs and 35 tons of equipment, state television reported. Officials said the quake killed 150,000 head of cattle, and health officials were trying to dispose of the rotting carcasses, fearing contamination of water supplies and the spread of infectious diseases. The geophysics center at Tehran University reported 60 aftershocks Sunday. It said the strongest jolted Rasht on the Caspian Sea and measured 5.7 on the Richter scale. Television reports said the jolt touched off a landslide that blocked the 35-mile road between Rasht and Rudbar, a critical route for relief supplies. It gave no further details. There were no reports of casualties. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage, while one of magnitude 6 can cause severe damage. Thursday's quake registered between 7.3 and 7.7 on the scale, which measures energy released by an earthquake. The geophysics center also reported a moderate earthquake measuring 4.9 in southern Iran Sunday morning. No casualties or damage were reported. Iran's news agency said the quake ``buried villages on mountaintops and in inacessible valleys under tons of rocks, cutting off the routes with the outside world.'' In Rudbar, dozens of Iranian military helicopters flew relief supplies into makeshift airstrips on a small island in a river that flows through the agricultural city. Yawning cracks in the earth, measuring up to a foot wide, testified to the quake's ferocity. Thousands of tents have been set up by the Red Crescent to house people in Rudbar, where an estimated 95 percent of the buildings were destroyed or damaged. The death toll from Thursday's quake surpassed a temblor that killed 25,000 people in nearby Soviet Armenia in December 1988, and a quake in Iran in 1978 that also killed 25,000. The quake's toll was the highest anywhere since July 28, 1976, when an estimated 200,000 people were killed in China by a quake.

DOC.HEAD: First U.S. Aid Shipment Arrives for Iran Quake Victims
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to delete reference to weight in lead, UPDATE with 2nd U.S. plane to arrive late Sunday EST; Pickup 5th, `The quake...'
DOC.TEXT: A cargo jet carrying U.S. aid for Iranian earthquake victims arrived Sunday, becoming the first private American relief mission to this country after more than a decade of bitter relations. ``To be on the ground here in Tehran is a very special feeeling for us,'' said Stephen M. Johnson, president of Americares, a private U.S. relief organization based in New Canaan, Conn. ``We are trying to fulfill the needs of the Iranian government.'' Americares flew in 84,000 pounds of supplies to Tehran after the Iranian government said it would accept humanitarian assistance from the United States for victims of Thursday's devastating earthquake in northwestern Iran. In Washington, Renee Bafalis, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Agency for International Development, said a Red Cross charter flight carrying supplies donated by the U.S. government was scheduled to arrive in Tehran late Sunday. The quake killed 50,000 people and wounded 200,000, according to a senior Iranian official quoted in the English-language Tehran Times. Official radio put the death toll at 48,000. The U.S. relief shipment included everything from bandages and antiseptic burn cream to orange slices in syrup and tents with built-in fiberglass frames. The cargo palletes heaped with supplies each bore an American flag and a hand-lettered sign in Farsi reading: ``From the American people to the Iranian people with very great affection and love, we offer you these things.'' Americares officials said they received scores of telephone calls both opposing and supporting the relief effort even before the shipment left Connecticut on Saturday. Some callers criticized the group for helping Iran, saying the Islamic government would not return the favor if the situation was reversed and Americans were suffering. The U.S. relief shipment also had critics in Iran. The radical newspaper Jomhuri Islami urged Sunday that no help be accepted from the United States and other countries whose hands ``are stained with the blood of the Iranian people.'' But the Foreign Ministry said Sunday Iran would accept all aid ``due to the magnitude of the disaster.'' The U.S. shipment was the first of its kind to be accepted by Iran since the hostage crisis of 1979-80, when 52 Americans were held at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran for 444 days. Iran is also believed to have influence with the Shiite Moslem extremists holding 16 Western hostages, including six Americans, in Lebanon. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. But Americares officials said the scope of the human disaster in northwestern Iran meant that political differences had to be put aside. ``It's a disaster we haven't seen the likes of, even in Armenia,'' said Johnson, referring to the December 1988 quake in the Soviet republic of Armenia that killed an estimated 25,000 people. ``When you have a disaster of this magnitude you have to set aside differences and come on over and help,'' said Doyt L. Conn, a project director for Americares. The Iranian air force ground staff at the miltary field in Tehran where the supplies were unloaded seemed slightly taken aback at the amount of aid. Ducking into the plane's cargo deck to confirm that the Americans had indeed brought emergency supplies, they emerged grinning. ``Thank you,'' said one officer on condition of anonymity. ``The quake area is like a leveled graveyard. It's terrible.'' The Americares group praised the speed with which the plane was unloaded but was not told how the supplies would be distributed. The Americans waited on the ground for about four hours, hoping that someone from the Iranian Red Crescent Society, the equivalent of the Red Cross, would come to greet them. But nobody showed up. After a slight delay in collecting their passports, the Americans departed, expecting to return to the United States by early Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Zodiac Victim Dies, Serial Shooter Stalks City's Defenseless
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Police believe ...,' to CORRECT Proce's birthdate to May 20 sted May 12. Quote in 4th graf from note is CQ.
DOC.TEXT: The city's ``Zodiac'' gunman became a killer Sunday when a 78-year-old man died, 3{ weeks after he was shot in the back by the letter-writing attacker, a hospital administrator said. Joseph Proce, the third of four people the gunman shot, went into cardiac arrest at Jamaica General Hospital at 10:25 a.m. and died about 40 minutes later, said administrator Ole Pedersen. Proce, who walked with a cane, was shot in the back as he walked near his Queens home on May 31. He lost a kidney and never left the hospital's surgical intensive care unit, Pedersen said. A note was discovered near the street where Proce was shot. It read simply, ``Zodiac _ Time to Die.'' The gunman also wrote police, ``The third sign is dead on May 31 1990 2:04 a.m. white old man with a cane shoot in front of house.'' Police believe the victims have been chosen because of their birthdates; Proce was a Taurus born May 20, 1912. The Zodiac victims also are vulnerable. Besides Proce, they have been a 50-year-old man who used a cane to steady a childhood limp; a 33-year-old man who was drunk, and a sleeping homeless man. The Zodiac gunman has written letters to news media and police detailing the shootings, which began in March. In a November letter to police, Zodiac threatened to kill 12 people, one for each astrological sign.
