The latest shooting was before dawn Thursday, when Larry Parnham, a 30-year-old homeless man, was wounded as he slept on a Central Park bench. The police Zodiac Task Force was doubled to nearly 50 officers, chief of detectives Joseph Borrelli said Friday. The latest victim apparently was chosen and stalked because of his astrological sign, police said. The other three each had different signs, but authorities didn't know whether the attacker knew that before they were shot. Parnham told detectives that days before the shooting, he was befriended by a stranger who asked him his birth date, Borrelli said. Detectives fear the gunman may stalk future victims the same way, and urged New Yorkers to beware of strangers asking their birth dates. A note claiming responsibility for the Central Park shooting was received Friday by the New York Post. The gunman also has claimed responsibility for the other shootings, which took place in March and May in an eight-block working-class section straddling the Brooklyn-Queens borough line. The latest note appeared identical to an earlier one sent to the paper by the gunman, said Post editor Jerry Nachman. Four similar notes have been found: one sent to police, one to the CBS show ``60 Minutes,'' and two left with shooting victims. All but one of the notes start with the words ``This is the Zodiac,'' and three contain the phrase ``the twelve sign will die when the belts in the heaven are seen.'' The birth dates of the other three victims correspond to astrological signs scrawled in the gunman's notes, Borrelli said. The notes recalled David Berkowitz, who killed six young men and women and wounded seven others in New York City in 1976 and 1977. He wrote letters to newspapers about the killing signed ``Son of Sam.'' The case also recalls the San Francisco ``Zodiac'' killer who, in a series of letters, took responsibility for 40 murders since the 1960s. Unlike Berkowitz, he was never captured. In the latest letter to the Post, the gunman claimed to be the same man who terrorized California. Police do not believe that. Astrologers had warned police that the first day of summer, when the Central Park shooting occurred, was considered a significant day because the zodiac changed from the sign of Gemini to the sign of Cancer. A note sent to police and dated Nov. 19, 1989, written by the gunman, threatened to kill 12 people and warned, ``When the Zodiacal light is seen Zodiac will spread fear.'' The zodiacal light is the diffuse glow seen in the west after twilight and in the east before dawn. Since March 8, the gunman has struck during the predawn hours on Thursdays, at 21-day intervals, except for a gap of 63 days between his second and third victims.

DOC.HEAD: Wreckage of Missing Plane Found; Bodies of FBI Agent and Trooper Found
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with investigators saying pilot had trouble with runway lights, wreckage found where radar signal disappeared.
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of an FBI agent and a Massachusetts state trooper were found Sunday in the wreckage of a small plane atop a mountain ridge in western Maine, a search and rescue official said. The missing Piper Cherokee vanished in rough weather late Monday, but FBI Agent Paul Cavanagh and Trooper Joseph Moynihan were not declared missing until Friday, said Paul Fournier, a spokesman for the Maine Warden Service. The wreckage was spotted on 1,400-foot-high Oak Ridge near Elliotsville, about three miles southwest of Greenville, by a helicopter pilot searching for the downed aircraft, Fournier said. Ground searchers reached the site by afternoon, Fournier said, and federal aviation officials would investigate the crash. The plane disappeared from radar screens around midnight Monday heading into the Greenville area near Moosehead Lake. The disappearance did not prompt a search because it happens frequently in the mountainous area, officials said. Fournier said Moynihan had indicated to air traffic control that he was having trouble activating the runway lights. At many small airstrips, an approaching pilot activates the runway lights by radio. A controller asked the pilot at least twice if he could see the runway lights and he answered ``no,'' Fournier said, adding that the pilot might have been too far from the runway or his view impaired by the dense forest. Lt. Carter Smith of the warden service said investigators believe the pilot ``was preoccupied with the landing lights and trying to focus on two or three different things'' while flying ``at a considerable speed.'' ``The plane was exactly where the radar showed it dropping off the scope,'' Smith said of the wreckage. ``They definitely were too low. ... It would appear that the left wing caught on a tree.'' In Boston, FBI Agent Stephen Morrill said Cavanagh was traveling to a training mission; State Police Maj. Robert Morse said the two men may have combined plans for a training session with a rafting excursion. FAA spokesman Mike Ciccarelli said Moynihan received a weather briefing Monday night for a flight from Worcester, Mass., to Greenville. When the pair did not arrive in Greenville, those they were to meet assumed they canceled travel plans because of stormy weather.

DOC.HEAD: Fletcher Says He Can't Persuade Bush To Accept Civil Rights Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 5th graf to insert that bill awaiting House committee action before reaching floor
DOC.TEXT: The head of the U.S. Civil Rights Commission said Sunday he had been unable to convince President Bush that a proposed civil rights bill would not lead to racial hiring quotas. But Arthur Fletcher said he hoped Bush would back away from a threat to veto the Civil Rights Act of 1990 unless it is modified. Fletcher, who appeared on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program with Jesse Jackson, was asked whether he believed Bush would veto the legislation, Fletcher responded, ``I hope not.'' But he added ``I can't tell you what the president is going to do.'' The bill is designed to overcome a series of Supreme Court decisions last year that made it more difficult for workers to sue employers for alleged job discrimination. But the Bush administration has sought changes in the measure, co-sponsored by Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and Rep. Augustus F. Hawkins, D-Calif. The bill may be brought up for Senate consideration this week. A similar version still awaits Judiciary Committee approval before being cleared for debate in the House. The administration has claimed that the bill, as drafted, would in effect force businesses to resort to hiring quotas to reduce their exposure to lawsuits. Backers deny that the bill requires quotas, either directly or indirectly. The White House has said it is willing to compromise, although some Republican leaders have expressed doubts that an accord can be reached. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said last week that Bush ``wants a bill he can sign.'' But Fletcher, appointed by Bush in February, said the commission voted 7-1 last week to support the legislation. However, the commission wants included a statement that there is no intention to force quotas. Fletcher said he had tried to convince administration officials that the bill as drafted would not do so. ``I obviously haven't convinced them yet, but ... we don't know the language in the bill yet. When we finally see what that says, we'll know whether there is a propensity for quotas or not,'' he said. GOP leaders have urged top congressional Democrats not to bring the bill to the Senate floor during the U.S. visit of South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela. The African National Congress official arrived last week and was scheduled to be in Washington from Sunday through Tuesday. He has other U.S. appearances scheduled through Saturday. On another matter, Jackson was asked if he would run for president in 1992. ``It's a matter that is worthy of serious consideration given the favor that we've gained among the public,'' said Jackson, who unsuccessfully sought the democratic presidential nomination in 1984 and 1988. ``But it's too early to make that decision.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Public Spending to Overshadow Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: Japanese and U.S. trade officials met Monday for talks on barriers to trade and investment that were expected to center on Tokyo's public works spending, officials said. Negotiators tackled Japan's land use policies, the Foreign Ministry said in a statement. U.S. officials say the policies have contributed to higher real estate prices that prevent foreign firms from setting up business here. Before the talks began, Japanese officials indicated they would push the United States to cut its federal budget deficit. U.S. officials, meanwhile, said they hoped Japan would agree to increase public works spending. Both nations agree the government should do more to improve the quality of life in Japan, and in turn encourage more imports, but they differ widely over exactly how much more spending Tokyo should promise in the talks. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has endorsed a $2.68 trillion 10-year public works package. But Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Linn Williams and other U.S. officials say that figure would not result in a sizable fall in Japan's current account surplus. They say Japan should spend one-tenth of its gross national product each year on public investment instead of the current 6 percent to 7 percent. Williams, in an interview with Kyodo News Service here, said he would be satisfied if Japan committed itself to spending at least $3.23 trillion over 10 years. Japanese officials acknowledge the need here for better airports, roads, sewers and parks. But they oppose committing a set percentage of GNP to such projects because it would limit the government's flexibility. Economists say Japan's booming economy has a limited capacity to absorb a significant increase in public spending without stimulating inflation. U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the talks, which began Monday, were to fine-tune the wording of a final report. Media reports said disagreements remained over details of measures to be adopted. Both sides hope to complete the final report before the summit of seven major industrialized nations begins in Houston on July 9. President Bush proposed the talks, dubbed the Structural Impediments Initiative, last July, to help cut Japan's massive trade imbalance with the United States. The talks are aimed at reforming business practices and policies that are believed to act as structural trade and investment barriers. In an interim report in April, Washington committed itself to cutting the federal budget deficit, encouraging savings, curbing excessive consumption and improving worker training and education. Japan said it would ease rules on opening retail stores, crack down on allegedly unfair business practices by corporate groups, consider revising land use policies to help reduce inflated real estate prices, and increase public works.

DOC.HEAD: Four Roman Catholic Bishops Meet With Married, Former Priests
DOC.TEXT: Four Roman Catholic bishops held a cordial but noncommittal meeting with a delegation of former priests who were stripped of their duties because they married and who want to return to work. The hour-long exchange came Saturday during a retreat for about 200 members of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops. ``They listened and took notes,'' said Terry Dosh, one of five former priests at the meeting. ``None of us got our hopes up that anything could happen immediately. We're realists.'' The four bishops, including Pierre Dumaine of the San Jose Diocese, agreed to take the request to their national committees for further discussion. At least one bishop appeared to support the former priests' cause. ``Within the framework of the discipline of the church, which has served the church well over the centuries, these men should be encouraged to put their life experience at the church's service,'' Bishop Donald Wuerl of Pittsburgh said in a prepared statement. The former priests are members of a Minneapolis-based group called CORPUS, or the Corps of Reserve Priests United for Service, which held an annual meeting over the weekend at San Jose State University. The group claims about 10,000 members, about half of them priests who married and are no longer allowed to serve. The meeting with the bishops was the first since the 1978 election of Pope John Paul II, who opposes letting married priests or women celebrate Mass or perform other priestly duties. CORPUS President Anthony Padovano said the group tried before to meet with bishops without success. CORPUS hopes the church will reconsider the ban on married priests this fall at an international meeting of bishops in Rome. Despite its insistence on a celibate clergy, the church in recent years has allowed married Episcopal priests to convert to Roman Catholicism, remain married and celebrate Mass, hear confessions and perform other priestly duties. ``That's a double standard,'' said Guy Murning, who was ordained as a Roman Catholic priest in 1970 but left eight years later to get married.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Percy Heads For Philippines, Gains Speed After Striking Palau
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with typhoon picking up speed, moving closer to Philippines. Pickup pvs 5th graf, `Storm signals...'
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Percy battered the Pacific island of Palau and then roared Sunday toward the Philippines, where 30 people were killed in a tropical storm last week. One child was killed on Palau, a newspaper said. The Manila weather bureau reported at 5 a.m. Monday that Percy, packing 93 mph winds, was centered about 465 miles east of the Philippine island of Samar. Percy was moving west-northwest at about 19 mph toward the islands of Catanduanes and southeastern Luzon island, which were expected to feel the effects of the storm late Monday, the weather bureau said. Storm signals were raised over southeastern Luzon and the central Visayas island chain, which includes Samar. In Palau, a young boy died Saturday night when he was swept by rain into mangrove trees near his home in the cluster of islands that comprise Palau, the Pacific Daily News of Guam reported. The storm passed 90 miles north of Palau, which is 800 miles south of Guam, according to the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Wind gusts of up to 103 mph blew off tin roofs of many buildings and knocked radio and television stations off the air, the Pacific Daily News said. Airline flights into the republic were canceled, the newspaper said. Earlier Sunday, the typhoon's winds battered Yap Island in the neighboring Federated States of Micronesia, collapsing about 30 houses and damaging banana and coconut plantations, police said. There were no reports of injuries on Yap. On Friday, Typhoon Ofelia swept over the eastern coast of Luzon, the main Philippine island, then struck Taiwan. Officials said at least 30 people were killed in the Philippines and at least seven in Taiwan. More than 84,000 people in the Philippines were forced to flee their homes because of flooding and landslides touched off by Ofelia, officials said. Officials were still assessing damage to crops and infrastructure. About 20 typhoons and tropical storms strike the Philippines each year.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Criticizes Aid to Savimbi
DOC.NOTE: EDS: 1st and 4th grafs to CORRECT spelling of guerrillas and guerrilla
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela criticized U.S. aid to non-communist guerrillas in Angola on Sunday shortly after he arrived in Washington for meetings with President Bush and congressional leaders. The pointed remarks were a sure sign that the African leader's three-day visit to the U.S. capital will have a decidedly more business-like flavor than his first four days in the United States, which were marked by a round of enthusiastic rallies and appearances that drew hundreds of thousands of supporters in New York and Boston. It is here where Mandela must make his case for continued U.S. economic sanctions against South Africa's government and press other items on his political agenda. During an unusual 20-minute question-and-answer session with reporters and editors from black-owned media concerns, Mandela said the United States should not be providing assistance to Jonas Savimbi, a guerrilla fighter seeking to overthrow the Angolan government. ``The United States and South Africa are the main countries that support Savimbi,'' he said. ``We strongly condemn that because ... independent countries should respect the political sovereignty and territorial integrity of Angola and no assistance should be rendered to Savimbi.'' Although questions were limited to representatives of black-owned media, other reporters were allowed to monitor the event. Mandela said he had not broached the subject of Angola with South Africa's white government and he refused to divulge what he is going to tell Bush when they meet Monday. Nevertheless, Mandela was explicit in saying ``no assistance'' should be given Savimbi's rebels, who have waged war for nearly 20 years against the Soviet and Cuban-backed Angolan government. Several of the reporters who were allowed to ask questions praised Mandela and asked what they could do to help the anti-apartheid struggle. ``Apartheid is still there,'' Mandela said. ``It is therefore necessary for you to continue to put pressure on your government and Congress'' to continue sanctions. Moreover, he said the African National Congress, with 20,000 exiles and enormous financial needs for new programs, must have money. ``Take part in the campaign to raise funds for the ANC,'' Mandela said. In a lighter vein, when one reporter asked about his health the 71-year-old leader said ``why don't you arrange a ball (a dance) and take me on.'' Asked whether he could control militant ANC youth in South Africa, Mandela acknowledged they are militant but that they also ``are highly disciplined'' and take orders from their leaders. He showed no bitterness about having spent 27 years in jail, saying he didn't want to dwell on the past. ``Let bygones, be bygones,'' he said when asked specifically about reports that the CIA had helped arrange his arrest in the early 1960s. When one of the reporters asked Mandela whether he would help end vestiges of racism in the United States, the South African responded, ``We are prepared to be guided by the black leadership.'' At a brief airport arrival ceremony earlier, Mandela had said he was ``greatly encouraged'' by his rousing reception in the United States. ``I come here to put the message out that sanctions must be intensified, and to ask for resources so we could be able to address the problems that are facing our country today,'' said the ANC deputy president. ``We have been greatly encouraged by the rousing reception which the American people in New York and Boston have given us. They have left us with the distinct impression that in this country we have our brothers and sisters who are committed to the fight against racial oppression in our country,'' Mandela said. Mandela noted that recent concessions by South African President F.W. de Klerk ``have raised the hope for peace.'' But he said the government yielded ``not because of a change of heart but because of the pressure put on the government inside the country and of the international community generally.'' Before getting down to business, the Mandela motorcade took the scenic route into town from National Airport, winding across the Potomac River and past the Lincoln Memorial and the Washington Monument. There was little traffic on the streets and no crowds lining the way. Once he reached the Madison Hotel, however, Manela was greeted by hundreds of people lined up behind ropes on the sidewalk across the street from the hotel. Some danced and waved banners. Security was tight. His only other announced events Sunday were a reception for African diplomats and a visit to a meeting between ANC members and South African exiles living in the Washington area. Both were closed to reporters. Mandela's wife, Winnie, attended a church service Sunday afternoon to honor South African women. Washington Mayor Marion Barry, on trial on drug and perjury charges, was not present at airport welcoming ceremonies, but Leila McDowell of the communications company helping with the Mandela arrangements said the mayor was invited. She said the mayor said he would not be able to attend because of his trial. Barry's wife and son were among those greeting Mandela. On Monday, Mandela meets with Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III. On Tuesday, he becomes one of only a handful of private citizens who have addressed a joint session of Congress. ``Mr. Mandela is a working statesman,'' said Roger Wilkins, national coordinator of Mandela's visit. ``This is a visit to official Washington, really.'' During his three-day stay, he also will speak to 19,000 people at a sold-out rally at the Washington Convention Center and visit labor leaders. In advance of Mandela's arrival, Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen told reporters that Bush and other U.S. officials are eager to hear Mandela's view on how he envisions a post-apartheid society in South Africa. ``The main emphasis of the meeting (with Bush) is negotiations and how to we help promote negotiations,'' Cohen said. The ANC and the de Klerk government held their first talks last month over obstacles to negotiations for a new constitution. Mandela has said the next problem to resolve is who sits at the negotiating table. Cohen said that among the questions U.S. officials have for Mandela is what would be the format for negotiations, what are his constitutional ambitions for South Africa and what are his economic models. The United States also disagrees with Mandela's unbridled support for Cuban leader Fidel Castro, Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi and Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat. Mandela says he won't criticize their human rights records because they've been strong backers of the anti-apartheid movement. Jesse Jackson, who is promoting Mandela's visit, said Sunday on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program that Mandela's support for Castro must be put in an African context. Castro sent Cuban troops to help drive South Africans out of Angola, Jackson noted. Cohen said the United States can't relax sanctions, which include a ban on new U.S. investment in South Africa and a trade embargo on items such as oil and agricultural products, until the white government meets a list of conditions set out in the 1986 Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act. De Klerk has satisfied all of those conditions with the exception of two: releasing all political prisoners and lifting a state of emergency in the Natal province, where ANC members are waging a bloody political battle with the supporters of Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, who heads the Zulu-dominated Inkatha movement.

DOC.HEAD: LULAC Rejects Old Guard; Incumbent Concedes Before Vote
DOC.TEXT: A new slate of officers for the nation's oldest Hispanic advocacy group was elected by acclamation Sunday during a raucous convention that ended with a pledge of unity. ``We will work together,'' said Jose Velez after he was sworn in as president. The League of United Latin American Citizens, which has 110,000 members, is the nation's oldest and largest Hispanic advocacy organization. Its 61st annual convention, held here this week, was rife with accusations of vote-buying and election fraud. Proceedings were stopped often during Sunday's general assembly as delegates tried to shout each other down over parliamentary procedure. Disgruntled supporters of outgoing two-term president Jose Garcia De Lara accused Velez, a Las Vegas entrepreneur, of buying the presidency. Velez supporters said De Lara, a San Antonio, Texas, architect, used heavy-handed tactics to maintain power like suspending and expelling members. But both camps called the convention atmosphere standard LULAC operating procedure and a healthy expression of the democratic process. ``Sometimes Latinos are so Americanized that they do the same things Democrats and Republicans do,'' Arnold Torres, LULAC national political adviser, said Friday. Sunday's real battle centered on whether 43 recently formed local councils, made up primarily of Velez supporters, would be able to vote. Most of the local councils are made up of Filipino-Americans from California, and the De Lara supporters argued that LULAC's constitution says the bodies must be at least two-thirds Hispanic. They said Velez's effort to bring in the Filipino-American contingent amounted to vote-buying. Velez supporters countered that De Lara was trying to limit his opponent's backing by keeping the councils out. After hours of unruly debate, a roll call vote was ordered Sunday afternoon to decide the council question. About 40 votes before the tally would have been final, De Lara suddenly appeared on stage and withdrew his candidacy, saying, ``The people have spoken.'' With a graciousness rarely seen during the four-day convention, De Lara pledged his full support to Velez as the two men stood arm-in-arm. One by one, all other incumbents then withdrew. At a news conference later, Velez said an early order of business would be returning LULAC's national headquarters to Washington, D.C., from San Antonio. Velez also said he would investigate all suspensions and expulsions under De Lara and review all lawsuits in which LULAC is involved.

DOC.HEAD: 2-Year-Old Battered Boy Dies in Coma After Life Support Removed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `An autopsy ...,' to CORRECT that coroner from Allegheny County sted Warren and clarify that he ruled death homicide. Picks up 7th graf pvs: `Warren County ...'
DOC.TEXT: A 2{-year-old boy who spent all but seven weeks of his life in a coma after a severe beating by his mother has died after his father allowed the hospital to turn off life support machinery. A coroner said Sunday that the boy's death was a homicide that resulted from the December 1987 beating. ``This was the most difficult decision of my life,'' David M. Crane said in a statement. His son, Leslie Michael Crane, died Saturday. Hospital officials had urged Crane for a year to permit them to turn off Leslie's respirator, but Crane would not because he feared his wife could then face murder charges. Tracey Jean Crane, 26, of Warren County was convicted in 1988 of assault for beating her son repeatedly after his birth on Oct. 16, 1987. An autopsy showed Leslie died Saturday of brain injuries suffered in a December 1987 beating, said Allegheny County Coroner Joshua Perper, who ruled the death a homicide. Warren County District Attorney Joseph A. Massa Jr. said he expected to announce Monday whether he will file any new charges against Mrs. Crane, who is serving a six- to 20-year prison sentence. The child was 7 weeks old when he was admitted to Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh with a severe brain injury he suffered in a beating by Mrs. Crane. His leg had been broken and his skull fractured in two earlier beatings. Leslie remained in a vegetative state for the rest of his life, connected to the respirator. The baby grew teeth and gained weight, but showed no other signs of improving. ``It was apparent the first hour he was here that he was a profoundly injured child and it was unlikely we could make any kind of a difference,'' said Dr. Ann Thompson, director of critical care medicine at Children's Hospital. The boy died at 2:29 a.m. Saturday. Hospital officials declined to say when they shut off the respirator. ``I became convinced that morally, ethically and practically, it was time to commit Leslie to the mercy of God,'' said Crane, of Turtle Creek. His statement was issued by his attorney, George C. Entenmann. Children's Hospital president Edwin K. Zechman Jr. said the hospital had planned to ask the court to appoint a new guardian for the child. Costs in the hospital's respiratory care unit run about $1,000 a day. Hospital spokeswoman Lynn McMahon would not say how the bills were being paid. Entenmann would not comment on whether Crane had agreed to allow the life-support removal in exchange for leniency for his wife. The lawyer said the boy's burial arrangements would be private.

DOC.TEXT: The economic merger of the Germanys on July 1 probably will be a double-edged sword for the rest of Europe. Experts feel it will spur general economic growth and speed the march toward a single European market, but also may give West Germany, already the strongest economy by far, even more influence over the continent's economic affairs. The Germans believe they have a strategy that will merge the two economies with minimum shock to the rest of Europe, but there are unknowns. If the union increases inflation, German interest rates may rise and the other Western European economies, linked in an exchange-rate system, may have to follow.

A man and his two sons lost in a cave for five days without food or water survived by sitting quietly to save energy and reciting Bible scriptures to remain hopeful, the father said Sunday. ``Toward the end, we figured we were going to die,'' Gary Lutes said. ``We were happy it would be all three of us together and not just one. We figured that was better than continuing on like that.'' Lutes, 37, a Tampa, Fla., land surveyor, and sons Gary Jr., 13, and Timothy, 9, were rescued from a West Virginia cave Saturday, state police said. They had been lost since Monday. They were taken to Rockingham Memorial Hospital in Harrisonburg, Va., where they were listed in stable condition Sunday.

Sen. Dave Durenberger was cautioned by his attorney in 1986 about accepting government reimbursement for stays in a Minneapolis condominium, according to documents, despite his contention this month that he had no reason to doubt the propriety of the plan. Durenberger, R-Minn., collected $40,055 in per diem payments from the Senate from 1983 to 1989 for staying in the condominium. He was part owner from 1983 to 1987, and says he sold the facility in April 1987 _ a deal called a sham by the special counsel for the Senate Ethics Committee. The propriety of Durenberger accepting reimbursement for staying in the condominium _ with a bedroom, bathroom, kitchen and sitting area _ is one of the principal areas of investigation for the Senate panel. After a 15-month investigation of alleged financial irregularities by the 55-year-old Republican, the committee soon will decide whether he willfully violated the rules and deserves punishment.

Republicans can't wait to get their hands on an upcoming book by the ex-wife of Democratic Gov. James Blanchard. Nervous Democrats wish they could put it on hold until after the November elections. Paula Blanchard says both sides are overreacting. Her book covering the 1987 breakup of her 21-year marriage to Blanchard is due out in July. Blanchard, who last year married Janet Fox, his former secretary, is favored for re-election this fall over likely GOP opponent John Engler, the state Senate majority leader. Paula Blanchard's book _ ``'Til Politics Do Us Part'' _ is a question mark in the campaign, but Michigan's former first lady predicts it won't affect the election.

The immigrant kids are retired now, but they still celebrate their exploits as members of the ``Deadline Gang.'' The youthful alliances forged during the 1920s and 1930s will be renewed this Saturday when the gang _ children of immigrants who moved to western Massachusetts in the 1900s _ gets together for a sixth time. The memories come tumbling out when members of the ``Deadline Gang,'' recall growing up in a gritty railroad town when the century was young. For Lester Lamothe, it was picking nuggets of reusable coal from the piles dumped at the railroad yards. For Cy Conner, it was playing ``the whip,'' hanging on to the back of a Model T spinning across a frozen river. For John DeChaine, it was swiping ears of corn to roast on summer bonfires.

DOC.HEAD: The West German Mark's Future is Anybody's Guess
With AM-Germany-Europe, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Foreign exchange dealers agree the first trading day after the powerful West German mark becomes East Germany's currency should be calm, but what happens next is a matter of argument. July 1, when the merger takes place, is ``a special day of course ... in particular for the history of this country, but in economic terms, the world will not be so different from June 30,'' said Peter Pietsch, an economist with Commerzbank in Frankfurt. West Germany will convert East German marks at the generous 1-1 rate for the first 4,000 and 2-1 above that total. The government is printing 120 billion marks _ $70 billion _ for the conversion, which will increase West Germany's money supply by 10 percent. Recently, the mark has been strong in relation to the dollar and Japanese yen, against which it floats freely, but weaker within the nine-currency European Monetary System, which limits its movements. Bulls believe the mark will be pushed higher by Germany's expected economic expansion and possible increases in interest rates to check inflation. Bears worry about political uncertainty and inflation. Robin Aspinall, director of currency economics at the London investment firm Hoare Govett Ltd., sees a rise in value to 1.40 marks to the dollar from the current 1.68, and perhaps even to parity in three or four years. ``You have the perfect conditions for a strong currency,'' he said. ``It's right out of the textbook. Of the major currencies, I would back the deutsche mark against all comers.'' Pietsch expects an increase to 1.60 to the dollar within a year, but no more. Stephen King, international economist with the London investment firm James Capel and Co., feels the mark will weaken against the dollar and yen, but rise against other European currencies.

DOC.HEAD: Sources Say First Unified Budget Will Have 45 Billion Mark Debt
DOC.TEXT: The first federal budget of a unified Germany in 1991 will be in deficit by more than 45 billion marks, or $28 billion, West German government financial sources say. According to a draft report from the West German finance ministry, a copy of which was obtained Sunday by The Associated Press, 14 billion marks, or $8.75 billion, of the 1991 deficit will be the result of absorbing the East German budget after unification. The report also estimated East Germany would receive about 22 billion marks ($14 billion) in the second half of 1990 and 35 billion marks ($22 billion) in 1991 to help cover unification costs. The money would come from the German Unity Fund, a venture set up by the West German government to raise money on the bond market to help finance unification, the report said. On July 1, East Germany will merge its economy with West Germany, ruled by the powerful West German mark, and shed 40 years of rigid socialist economic policy for free-market rule. West Germany's portion of the 1991 estimated deficit, 31.46 billion marks or $19.7 billion, compares with an actual 1989 deficit of 19 billion marks, or $12 billion. The draft report says total German government expenditures in 1991 are expected to be 324 billion marks ($202 billion). Revenues are expected to total 292.5 billion marks ($183 billion). West Germans are worried how much unification may cost them in terms of either higher taxes or inflation, but Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government has promised no new taxes. The report also said higher taxes would not be necessary.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Defends Administration's Attack on S&L Fraud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh on Sunday fired back at critics who say the Bush administration is not moving aggressively to ferret out savings and loan fraud. ``We're going after savings and loans crooks, whether they're Republicans or Democrats, North, South, East and West. And we've compiled ... a very impressive record on that score,'' Thornburgh said during an appearance on the CBS-TV program ``Face the Nation.'' His comments came as Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said it was time for Democrats and Republicans to stop trying to affix blame for the S&L scandal and concentrate on catching culprits. Brady, appearing on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program, agreed with members of Congress who have said the focus should shift from fingerpointing to prosecuting S&L industry officials who violated the laws. ``What the American people want is a dedicated, organized, calm approach to cleaning up the problem (and) ... make sure to prosecute the criminals involved,'' Brady said. Brady recently revised the Bush administration's estimate on the cost of the savings and loan bailout to as high as $130 billion. Thornburgh denied that prosecutors have targeted lower-level employees of failed institutions rather than top officials. ``I think the record clearly indicates the contrary. You've seen executive after executive convicted, sentenced to jail,'' he said. But Thornburgh couldn't say how many new indictments have been obtained since Bush took office in January 1989. ``There's a continuum there of activity on (the part of) the Department of Justice,'' he said. ``We don't keep score by who's the president at the time.'' Members of Congress have criticized the slow pace of prosecutions in the saving and loans scandal. But administration officials have said the investigations of financial mismanagement and fraud are extremely complicated and will take time to resolve. Thornburgh said Sunday that something ``more important than the numbers'' should be addressed, ``and that's the commitment.'' Administration officials said last week there were 791 fraud convictions in 1989 and $100 million in stolen funds was recovered. Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., urged against focusing on which political party is more to blame for the savings and loan debacle, saying ``that's history. We ought to go after the crooks.'' Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, said that while a Republican administration failed to adequately regulate the savings and loan industry, Congress also should bear some of the blame. ``The issue is, do we go after those involved?'' said Panetta. In recent days members of the Bush administration have said the Democratic-controlled Congress should accept part of the blame for the S&L mess. Likewise, Democrats have been quick to claim that the crisis emerged largely because of lax regulation of the savings and loans by the Republican Reagan administration. Brady, meanwhile, said Sunday that the government should dispose of real estate holdings acquired as part of the growing savings and loan scandal even if it has to offer more favorable discounts. ``The government shouldn't be in the real estate business,'' he said on the ABC program. As part of the bailout of the ailing savings and loan industry, the Resolution Trust Corp. is selling about 36,000 properties, originally valued at $14.9 billion, often at discount. Most of the properties are in Texas, although they are scattered through 45 states. Brady said Sunday that part of the increased cost estimate of the S&L cleanup was sagging real estate industry which has affected the sale of the distressed properties held by the RTC. The RTC was created to administer the savings and loan cleanup.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Overtakes U.S. As World's Biggest Aid Donor
DOC.TEXT: Japan surpassed the United States to become the biggest donor of government aid to the Third World in 1989, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said. The achievement could soften criticism that Japan, with its immense financial strength, has not done its share to help developing countries. Japan's total aid effort in 1989 was $9 billion, compared with $7.7 billion for the U.S., the Paris-based organization of industrial democracies said in a report. The U.S. figure represented a decline of 27 percent from 1988, after adjusting for inflation. The decline meant that U.S. aid as a share of gross national product declined from 0.21 percent in 1988 to 0.15 percent last year _ the worst performance among the OECD's main aid donor countries. Joseph Wheeler, chairman of the OECD's Development Assistance Committee, told a news conference Sunday the U.S. aid figure for 1989 understates the U.S. effort in the same way the 1988 total overstated aid disbursements. If U.S. contributions to multilateral aid institutions were spread evenly over the two years instead of bunched more heavily in 1988, Wheeler said, the level each year would have been $8.9 billion, equivalent to 0.18 percent of GNP in 1988 and 0.17 percent in 1989. But the OECD said U.S. bilateral aid to the Third World has fallen steadily in recent years. Wheeler said he expects the U.S. will lift its aid effort to at least $9 billion this year. He said U.S. contributions to multilateral aid institutions should return to normal levels in 1990, and substantial new aid programs in Central America are likely. But this probably won't be enough to enable the U.S. to regain its number one slot, Wheeler said, since Japan plans to spend at least $31 billion on aid over the next three years. Wheeler said government assistance to developing countries from all sources in 1989 totalled $51.3 billion, scarecely changed from the year-earlier figure of $51.7 billion. The total resource flow _ including private funds and export credits _ to these countries is estimated at $109 billion, up 4.5 percent from 1988. Wheeler said the aid effort of the OECD's 18 richest countries has increased in real terms at an average rate of 2.9 percent a year, or a total of about 33 percent in the past decade. Wheeler said the aid effort of Western industrialized nations in 1989 wasn't affected by assistance to Eastern Europe. Most donor countries have indicated future aid to Eastern Europe won't be diverted from traditional aid recipients, he said. The OECD said Scandinavian countries continued to provide the most official aid last year as a percentage of GNP, led by Norway with 1.02 percent. The OECD's member nations are: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the United States and West Germany. The third biggest donor by dollars, after Japan and the U.S., was France with $5.14 billion followed by West Germany with $4.95 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Says Gas Prices Down Four-Tenths of a Cent
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices dropped slightly over the past two weeks as retailers passed along a decline in wholesale gas prices, according to a nationwide survey of retailers. The average price for a gallon of gas, including all taxes, was 117.68 cents a gallon on June 22, down 0.42 cents from June 8, the Lundberg Survey said Sunday. Retailers passed through lower wholesale prices in most places, but not on the West Coast, said survey manager Trilby Lundberg. Refinery output there was affected by summer pollution control laws and retail demand continued strong, Lundberg said. The average prices at self-service stations, which now account for about 83 percent of all retail sales: regular unleaded, 105.83 cents a gallon; premium unleaded, 123.08 cents a gallon, regular leaded, 106.44 cents a gallon. At full-service stations: regular unleaded, 132.31 cents a gallon; premium unleaded, 145.97 cents a gallon; regular leaded, 129.31 cents a gallon.
